No alcohol which would have been nice with the curry

Atmosphere was simple 

We would go again for the food
author: Bart F.

description:
We were walking to a vegetarian restaurant at Kearney. As we are turning to Kearney from Bush. We saw a small Thai restaurant around the corner. 

The first impression is clean. The lunch menu is not especially unique, except for a few with house name. We ordered noodle curry and its house special fried rice. The food is good. We will definitely be back when we are in the area.
author: Lionel W.

description:
OK food but I prefer Osha Thai better. This place is just a bit more convenient to my office. Restaurant is small and colorful. Portions smaller than other places, but enough to fill you up. Gets busy during lunch rush. There are many other places to eat on the same block, but if you're craving Thai, this will do the trick.

- Papaya Salad: refreshing
- Noodles: OK nothing special, not spicy
- Thai Iced Tea: very milky and sweet
author: Linda C.

description: Thai food is mediocre here for the price but nothing exceptional - we ordered fresh spring rolls wrapped in crepe, which I thought was unusual (instead of rice paper)  but I like the concept!  Unfortunately, the crepe was not fresh but rather hard around the edges, difficult to bite off -not soft as one would expect for crepes.  Plating was also sloppy and there was only 1 other couple in the restaurant besides us - not a full house.  The Pad Woon Sen was very tasty but very spicy, and I thought how odd that the waitress did not bother to ask how spicy we would like our food.  The best dish for the entire evening were the mangoes, which were fragrant and just perfect in ripeness!  They covered up for the sweet rice that fell sorely flat, a clump of mess, a day or two old and embarrassed to be next to a delicious fruit.  Banana House, I think you guys could do a lot better than this on Christmas day.  Don't cook if you need to stay home and rest.
author: Susie D.

description: We get there on a Sunday afternoon. The restaurant nearly empty. We sat and wait for the next 15 min for someone to come get our orders and bring us water. Nothing. So we left.
author: Lorrayne S.

description: Are you kidding me?? You stupidly forget my meal and people came and ate and left while I waited. Don't ever sit outside, you are invisible to staff. Enormous mistake!! Won't be back, of course.
author: Crissy C.

description: Ordered pad see ew.....and didn't like it. I've tried this dish in many Thai places, so I know what to expect. The worst part: the meat. It was baaad... On top of that....small serving portions. I left hungry. The staff was friend tho. Not coming back.
author: Guillermo N.

description:
This place probably doesn't need another person calling them average, but *damn* this is average.  I'm giving them an extra star for having brown rice available, except they charge an extra dollar.  For an extra dollar I could buy 10X as much rice, so no extra star.

The layout really sucks -- if you order to-go, then you are shoved around by every child of the corn that walks in.  How does this place attract so many people?  Zombie style.  Sorry, so the food lacks flavor, the portions don't justify the cost, and they used squash instead of pumpkin.  I know, pumpkin is a squash.  But this squash was not a pumpkin.

I do like the paint color, but enough to reward some points.
author: Lost S.

description: Wow hate to break it to you but this was terrible.  I ordered the pad kee mao which was supposed to have broccoli, tomato, basil and bell pepper and tofu.  Instead, it had only rice noodles, broccoli (with the stems and leaves..that's not basil) and the worst tofu I've had in years.  There was literally a point that I was mid chew on a tofu cube and decided to forego and spit out my mouthful into a napkin to throw away.  No flavor, cold and disgusting.  Definitely won't be coming back here.  Sad because I love Thai...
author: Madeleine M.

description:
Working in a close proximity I often visit this place and get takeout. Spicy cat fish and salmon curry is awesome! The absence of the website is really taking this place down. Very behind the modern times. But the food is authentic and tasty. Some dishes like papaya salad is a miss. Finally brown rice option, way overdue but welcome of course. 

Prices are average. Recommended.
author: Xela H.

description:
Just delicious.  Even though the place was packed, I was still seated right away and received my food quickly after ordering.  The service was really impressive and I loved being able to sit outside on such a beautiful day.

The food was also delicious.  The salad has a wonderful dressing on it that is cooling and perfect for any of the main dishes, especially the spicy ones.  I ordered the Prik Khing with chicken which was just heaven on a plate.  The veggies were perfectly crunchy and the chicken was great quality.  Warning: this dish is for those who love spicy food!  If you can't take the heat, order anything but this. I also tried the Pad See Ew which is always my favorite thai dish.  This one had a lot of fresh broccoli and did not disappoint.  I needed some chili paste to bump up the flavor a bit, though.  

All in all, I highly recommend.  I'll be back to try some more dishes and next time I'll splurge for their mango sticky rice dessert.
author: Jordan F.

description:
I came here with a co-worker for a lunch yesterday and it was really good! I had Pad Thai with tofu and she had red curry with chicken. My pad thai was hot and a bit spicy which is a nice change. I have tasted pad thai dishes all over bay area and must say that this was a very good one. The tofu was prepared very well too! I am a vegetarian, so i am picky about how I like my tofu cooked. As i've heard, the red curry was a bit spicy too... she didnt finish it. But thats understandable, since spicy dishes will fill you up faster. 
The atmosphere was nice too, even though we ate outside. (they have a couple of tables outside). Definitely recommend you check out this place. Their prices are below average for FiDi too. :)
author: Yuliya K.

description: Food was good they do not bill separately if multiple people go together.
author: R N.

description: I had the banana house ground chicken special on recommendation. A bit different than what I've seen on typical Thai menus which is nice. Taste was good. Not the cleanest place though.
author: Allen T.

description:
I walked into Banana House randomly one day during lunch without checking the reviews first - and I probably should have. I ordered the Mango Chicken, and, while the dish definitely looked very appealing (full review and photos on my food blog here: http://temptingdelights.wordpress.com/2012/07/13/banana-house-mangos-chicken-and-fog-for-lunch/), I found the curry sauce to be a bit watery and bland. 

Banana House is an okay place if you just want to grab a quick meal, but a bit on the expensive side if you're looking for something mind-blowing. I've definitely had way better Thai food before for cheaper. However, I did only try one dish, so I may have missed out on some of their specialities, which may be a lot better.
author: Krystal L.

description: Stopped in on a whim on my walk to work. Reasonable prices, great Pad Thai and excellent staff! My glass never went empty, service was quick, and they were very kind. I'll definitely be back!
author: Kristina C.

description: I wandered in off the street, really just looking for a place to park and a little lunch.  Even average quality Thai food would have been fine.  I then ordered the eggplant with garlic sauce, and my day got a whole lot better.  Spicy but subtle, and cooked with pride.  I noticed a lot of regulars filing in as I enjoyed my meal.  I'll be back, and give Banana House a strong thumbs-up.
author: Scott S.

description:
It was...okay.

My complaints:
1. WAY too loud
2. The pumpkin curry was made with butternut squash
3. I ordered a thai coffee and got a thai tea
4. my spring roll was cold
5. I didn't see a single banana in the entire place
6. It smelled funny (I think it was the candles on the tables)

What was good:
1. reasonably quick
2. reasonably priced
3. reasonably tasting

meh. three stars, but there's got to be something better out there...
author: Danielle L.

description:
A solid three stars but 4 stars for value.
Ambience: Not much to speak of. Basic settings and menus that could do with a clean.
Service: Very friendly waitress and fast response. 
Food: A pleasant surprise. We stopped in here on a whim for dinner and weren't expecting much but found a the two mains we ordered to be tasty and interesting. The sizes are more than enough (with the extra side of rice) for all but the biggest eaters. I had a spicy calamari dish and my friend a chicken cashew dish. Both were well seasoned and not your run of the mill "just drop lemongrass and ginger in it and call it good" type dishes you can get at some Thai places.
Price: ~$11 for a main with rice.
I'd go back as it was a cut above any other Thai I've had in SF.
author: Geoff A.

description: Right when we walked in, it looked really dirty and disorganized. The waitress didn't understand English much and we had to ask for refills and utensils multiple times. Food wasn't any special. Never go back again.
author: Cindy C.

description:
This place is really close to work an I was craving Thai food so I figure why not give it a try. The place is quite small and seating is very limited and there can be a wait time to be seated but they offer a to-go menu and are quite quick with getting you with your order out the door. 

I got the yellow curry with tofu and made it a combo which includes soup, salad, spring rolls, and your choice of Thai Coffee or tea. 

The soup is served in a very small bowl and tastes like vegetable broth.  The Thai Coffee was pretty good, not too sweet.  For the salad they used some type of curry/peanut dressing and it was delicious.  The Spring Rolls (2) were accompanied by a dipping sauce and were also very good.  Finally, the yellow curry tofu was just ok.  The curry was a bit oily/watery and the tofu was kind of dry. 

This place does not compare to Osha Thai but for the price, the food is pretty decent.  I'd probably go again and order the Pumpkin curry instead.
author: Cynthia P.

description:
The usual thai fare.

+1 star for some dishes that I don't see regularly - try the the spaghetti kee mao, like pad kee mao but with spaghetti noodles, its great, takes more thai-eem (time).

The fried chicken on fried rice is pretty damn good too
author: Noah P.

description:
The place is just average, especially consider other alternatives in the area for Thai or other Asian.  The lunch specials seem like a good deal but the quantity is a little less than other places because they put your entire entree into a bowl which is on a plate of rice and small salad.  I also decided to upgrade my meal with the Thai iced tea, spring rolls, and jasmine rice, but it's not worth it.  All of it was just ok and there wasn't enough flavor.  

I had the spicy eggplant with tofu and there was a good variety of vegetables and sauce but it was a little soggy and lost some of the natural flavor.  A friend had the pad thai and didn't have any complaints while another person also had the spicy eggplant but had the chicken.  The chicken was dry but passable due to the sauce.  Overally, a place I'm not interested in returning back to.
author: Jay N.

description:
2/5 skip it.

it was whatevs. i got the beef ginger lunch special, and the beef came out in that odd state where it's been overcooked, but could have been cooked longer for slight salvation. it was pretty bleh, and the roll that came with you could squeeze the oil out if it between your fingers. combined with the long wait for food when the lunch rush was over...meh.
author: Alvin D.

description:
This place has gone downhill since I worked in the area 2 years ago. It used to be consistently above average. Now . . .

Met some friends for lunch and I got the duck curry lunch plate ($7.95) with their combo special ($3) which adds 2 egg rolls and choice of Thai iced tea or coffee.

The flavor of the curry was OK, but there was hardly any duck and a few too many fresh grapes(??). The jasmine rice came preformed in that upside down bowl shape and I had the hardest time pulling it apart. That stuff was like a brick and obviously not fresh.

The side salad had some shredded cabbage on top of lettuce, but the lettuce consisted of two wedges off the end of the head of lettuce. You know the hard stuff where all the leaves connect? Inedible.

My friend that got fried chicken over fried rice said "Well, it's better than a Chicken McNugget." If that's not glowing praise, I don't know what is! ;-)

The eggrolls were alright and apparently the tofu noodle dish another friend got was tasty, but all in all a disappointing dining experience.
author: Andrew C.

description:
This place is pretty much par for the course.  Cheap thai food that's decent.  I had the pad see ew, and it was no better/no worse that other ones that I've had.  This all is pretty mush 3 star material.

However, I used to work long hours in the financial district, and the 4th star is for how fast the service is.  We used to have food delivered in, and these guys are extremely fast getting food there.  Most other places required a wait of 45 minutes to an hour.  We were able to get things as fast as 15 minutes.  Granted, it's not very far from Banana House to the Transamerica Building (where I worked) but I still think it's commendable.
author: Ken L.

description:
3.5 stars.
This is just above average.
Came here with work colleagues for lunch - arrived early so place was empty. It did fill up later on.

The others mostly ordered some seafood basil curry which looked ok and judging by the fact they ate it all was a good sign.

I had the mango curry which I was pleasantly surprised with. It's not the biggest portion but for an ok price and it being lunch time it was fine.

The pad see ewe was a bit dry and not flavorful enough - tasted like bland rice noodles...

The service was fast and water filled up regularly. No complaints there but nothing had that wow or stand out factor.

An above average place for lunch.
author: Nick L.

description: It's cool. They have a secret downstairs space. I likey for a quick Thai sit-down lunch. They are not afraid of serving spicy food and I am not afraid of eating it.
author: Andrew K.

description:
The place (tables, chairs, walls, plates, lights above the counter and tables) all need a very good cleaning.

Food was fine. Service was fast. Lots of choices. Good location -- but need to clean the place up. Make it look better.
author: John G.

description:
The place was OK.  Decent and quick lunch but nothing special.  

The duck curry that we ordered was a little bit oily to me.  The Pad Thai was ok.  Good portion.  Fast service.

Banana House is an OK place for lunch.
author: Liza T.

description:
Nothing really special about this place. The dishes are run of the mill - I got the pad thai, which was pretty good, and my friend got the pad see ew, which was way too salty. Average overall, but they are one of the few places open for dinner (until 9 pm) in the fidi.

I will say that my vegetarian roommate is not a fan of this place at all. I personally have not tried the vegetarian dishes, but would probably steer clear of them.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I work nights and some weekend days in the FiDi -- they're open late and 7 days a week, and their pickup/delivery speeds are blinding. Instant plus.

But, nobody gets excited about readily-available bad food. And that's the lovely thing about Banana House, their food has been uniformly pretty great. I don't agree with everything they do (grapes in duck curry for example) but generally I've had a good eating experience. 

Story: One time it was very cold, windy and rainy out and I ran down here to get my food and had forgotten my umbrella. The woman behind the counter took one look at me and poured me a hot cup of tea in a styrofoam cup to take with my pickup order. Awesome. I got rain in my tea. Double awesome.

The food's not going to change your life, but it's solid and dependable. Highly recommended over its next door neighbor, Bangkok Best.
author: Dara K.

description:
Came for a late lunch with my friends the other day so it wasn't really that packed. This is a pretty mom and pop shop I think. 
The food came out pretty fast which was good because I was STARVING! 
The thai ice tea didn't do much to quench my thirst since it was too sweet but eh most are aren't they? 

What I really liked was the fruit curry that they had. It's a vegetarian option and the fruits are lathered in a spicy red curry. I really like how the fruit gave the curry a tangy flavor. I've never had avocado or grapes or mango in a curry before but it was quite a surprise and is a DELICIOUS combination. If y'all want to try having fruit served in a different way I do recommend this!

The Portion size was just right though I can be a little more greedy to say I would have liked more rice to soak up the curry goodness. 

I do have to say that the side salad that came along with the curry and the rice was not good though. I dunno the veggies looked pretty limp once covered in this peanut derived sauce that they ladled overtop. I wasn't too fond of it and barely touched it. Too much sauce over the salad gave it kinda of a soggy texture. 

If I do come back it would be for the fruit curry!
author: Sharon Y.

description:
Mango curry with chunks of mango and basil leaves. Tasty!
Fast service.
Didn't expect to be charged an extra $1.50 for rice.
Dessert of fried banana was fried in a plain batter with a vaguely chocolate (corn) syrup.
The plain walls and kitchen counter prevent any ambiance of Thailand.
author: Ethan K.

description:
Entrees here all around $6.50. I highly recommend the garlic pan with beef (beef with garlic & pepper), though I do kinda wish there were more veggies. (Other people's dishes had more veggie-wise).
 
Good quality beef & great taste.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
A nice Thai option for a quick, cheap FiDi lunch.  They've got things down to a science, so expect the check on your table before you finish your last bite.

I was hoping for a little more heat from the Prik Sod with pork, which comes with sauteed onions, bell pepper, and jalapeno pepper.  It left a little sting on the tongue, but I was expecting to perspire.

It was good enough that I'll give it another go down the line.
author: Daryl E.

description:
Fine in a pinch. Not horrible, but certainly not great either. Don't go out of your way to eat here, but if you're in the neighborhood and looking for Thai food, it's fine.

The mango curry was a bit on the oily side, but mighty tasty.  Pad thai was pretty good, but I've had better.  Mango sticky rice was some of the better that I've tasted, but of the Thai restaurants I've been to, none of them have butchered it.

Ambiance is SORELY lacking, and it doesn't feel like the most hygienic joint, which is what bumped it from a 3 (for the food) down to a 2.
author: Kali M.

description: Decent Thai food in the financial district.  But lots of competition around, and there is nothing particularly special about this place that distinguishes it.  They have everything you are used to, but if it were me, I would take the hike and go to King of Thai a few blocks away if possible.
author: Mark M.

description: Quality was horrible. The food tasted like it had freezer burn and the food looked revolting. I got food poisoning, never going back.
author: Soo Hyun K.

description: Havent  been  there   for  about  a  year  (now  i  know  why)  I  had one  of  the   wost  Thai    meals  ever  in  San  Francisco...The   prad  pam  vegtables  tasted   like  they  were  cut  up     and  left   in  the  fridge  for  a  week.  (   and  they   still  gouge   you   for  rice  by  charging  extra)   its  probably   crappy  ownership  as  it  wwas  dead  @  1pm ..really  bad  stay  away
author: Tom J.

description:
They say the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting something to change.

Sadly, that's what the repeat visits here feel like...
With it being close to work and having a pretty decent set-up (limited but available outdoor seating and plenty of seating with the usual FiDi basement area), perhaps I keep hoping it'll be better next time.
But as said by many other reviewers before me, the flavor is bland and the dishes are not prepared well.  
My Pad Kee Mow was all lumpy and soggy and not spicy at all.
The spring rolls were wrapped in tortilla-like wraps and really bland.

Would appreciate a good Thai option on Kearny...
author: Carol K.

description: 3 stars. The Roti with Green Vegetarian Curry was decent though I wish they gave more Roti to go with the curry. Not a bad choice for fast and delicious Thai food a few blocks from work.
author: Tiffany L.

description: We stumbled upon this place. I always love Thai food so figured we would try it out. It's a tiny little place and the tables are tight. But it's a perfect place for lunch as food came out quickly, service was efficient and friendly. Everything was good. However, my Tom Kha was completely devoid of spiciness. From past experience with Thai places, Tom Kha is usually incredibly spicy or at least has a bit of heat. That was the only problem I had. Don't know if this is the norm here or if they thought I looked like a wuss who couldn't take it.
author: April S.

description:
This place is okay if you absolutely must have Thai food in the midst of FiDi and nothing else is close by. Otherwise, it's a true "Meh. I've experienced better." in terms of take-out.

I stopped by to pick up an order of pad see ew and the employee was quick in taking my order. They have this weird counter covering where if you are anywhere between 5 ft. and 5 ft. 5 inches, you end up eye-level with the cover and have to either stand tippy toe or hunch down in order to make eye contact with the employees.

The food came out before the ten minute estimation. What irked me was that no utensils were provided, they included two very thin napkins that could withstand nothing, and to top it all off, the portion filled up maybe half the take-out box. For almost $9, can I at least get a fork?
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I suppose I cannot rate a restaurant based on one dish; however, I took a look at the other dishes that my co-workers ordered and it just looks OK. 

I ordered fried spaghetti (which was cooked in a Thai style). It was OK, but looked messy. The presentation could have been made to be decently appealing. The portions are just a bit smaller than expected.

For delicious Thai food I like Osha's near Post and Leavenworth. I haven't been to "King of Thai" for a long time but I remember it being satisfying for those late night meals.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I was walking around the area at lunch time and was deciding what new place I wanted to check out.  Outside the door they had a sign saying "Free Soup" with purchase of any entree.  I thought, ok, I will give this place a try.  I went in and in the menu it had a combo that you can get a "Free Salad."  I thought this sounded great.  I will buy one entree and get a free soup and salad!  So I was looking at the menu deciding which soup and salad I wanted to choose with my lunch.  

When the waitress came, I told her I wanted to get the mango chicken curry that came with a free salad.  I told her which salad I wanted and she said, "Oh, you don't get to pick which salad."  I said ok and told her which free soup I wanted to get.  She said that I don't get to pick that either.  I was a little taken aback by that , but was still optimistic.

When the food came, the "Free soup" advertised was in a tiny tiny TINY minuscule bowl.  The free salad was more like garnish on the plate which was only some lettuce and maybe a piece of tomato.  The curry was ok, nothing special, but again the portion was really small.

I felt that I was lied to about the free soup and salad. I didn't get to pick which one I even wanted, and the food wasn't even that good.  One star because I left there hungry and mad!  I will NOT ever being going back, EVER.
author: Maria S.

description: Strolled past during a quiet midweek lunch hour. The on-table special (roti with yellow curry and tofu) was very very very good but the pik pao w/calamari was a huge miss. Service was a little slow (it almost seemed as if the guy was new, though?). Good Thai tea but even that is hard to do incorrectly.
author: Steve L.

description:
I tried the green curry and manga curry combo plates while here. Green curry (it's called something weird on the menu) had cucumbers in it, while the mango had big slices of fresh mango cut in.

It's good, but everything tastes rather heavy and dunked in grease (especially the egg rolls). Was also not a fan of the oily peanut butter dressing on the salads. I'd say that for the price, there's better places to be eating on this block of restaurants.

Service was also very slow and the dining area really loud. It does clear up significantly after 1pm though.
author: Janet J.

description:
This is my favorite Thai restaurant in the area. 

Just make sure to call your order in ahead of time if you're ordering to go. There isn't much waiting room in this place.

It's gets pretty packed around 12-1:30pm so be prepared if you plan on dining in. They also have more seating in. what seems to be, their basement. It's more spacious than the main floor, but unless you request to be seated there or have a large party, they won't seat you down there. It's less noisy and more private as well. (don't worry, it doesn't feel like a basement.)

Not too expensive and I'm almost always pleased... only had one occasion where the food wasn't up to par, but I've been going to this place FAITHFULLY for 2 years. Love it!!!
author: Marie T.

description:
I ordered food for delivery here and they cooked and delivered within 15 min! That's a great thing when you're starving. I prefer this "fast food" over the others.

Pros: fast delivery
author: Jenn Y.

description: Delicious!  Roti with green curry is a must. Decent prices. Cute hole in the wall eatery.  Friendly service.
author: Malia H.

description:
We flew in a candidate from the East Coast for a senior developer role.   A full day's worth of interview pretty much drains anyone emotionally, but we are kind enough creatures as to offer a decent lunch to people whom we might decide to hire.   One of my coworkers suggested Banana House since I veto'ed Osha Thai before anyone even had a chance to mention the name.   Since I'd never been here before, I was happy to acquiesce.

The decor leaves a helluva lot to be desired.  This place, with a small and very crowded upstairs and a slightly more spacious downstairs (though beware if you're claustrophobic because you're eating in the basement!)  We took a table downstairs and I ordered the Gang Traffic Jam, a curry combo with red curry, yellow curry, and green curry.  I made it a combo lunch, which includes a Thai Iced coffee and some egg rolls.

I must say the dish was very tasty, with extremely generous portions, and I think the quality is far superior to what you get at Osha Thai.   Next time I'm looking for good Thai food for lunch I'll certainly be heading this way from now on.   In short, if you're into decor and trendiness, go to Osha Thai.  If you just want some damn good Thai food,, head on over to Banana House.
author: David O.

description:
Perfectly serviceable Thai. They were busy the evening we went, but our server was attentive and kept our water glasses full. This is good, because the curry I got was pretty darn spicy! I do like spicy food, so this was a good thing. A surprise was that my curry came with brown rice, which was a nice, healthy, nutty option that went well with my dish.

We got the spring roll appetizer which was pretty good, though a bit pricey for what you got (but it's an app - isn't that always the way?). Overall, a tasty Thai joint, but not necessarily something to go out of your way for.
author: Jason W.

description: Huge, delicious crab rangoons. Prik Sod is scrumptious with a bit of spice from the jalapenos. Thai Iced Tea is one of the best I've had in San Franciso. I definitely recommend for lunch in FiDi or if you are feeling lazy and want takeout for dinner (as I did tonight, ha!).
author: Kandace H.

description:
I usually don't rate thai food so poorly, but this place really disappointed me today. I needed something soft since my teeth were bothering me, so I opted for tofu pad see ew and a Thai Iced Tea to sooth my aching tooth. Oh, and I really mean pad see EW...

The tea was fine, the food was not.

The pad see ew was so overdone, it smelled burnt before I even opened my to-go container. The tofu looked ok, albeit dried out, but it literally tasted charred, and my eggs were fried beyond recognition. I've eaten here  before, years ago, and felt that it was ok, but today just ruined it for me.

I think the veggies were fresh, but the noodles, tofu and eggs had probably been sitting in a pan all morning already.

It was quick and friendly service but my last "chewable" meal before getting wisdom teeth taken out, was NOT a wise choice to be had from here. Sadness.
author: Jessica P.

description: I want to share my experience with all Banana House customers and worn them to be careful and check bank statement after visiting this place. On 10/2/2012 I went with my friend for dinner. The service was horrible and super slow. Food usually was good but not anymore. I gave them my card in order to charge me for my dinner and after a while the waiter got back to me and said that they will not charge me because they run out of paper. Instead, they asked to pay in cash. I paid the whole amount in cash and I left. When I logged in to check my back statement online, I figured out that Banana House waiter have already charged me twice for the dinner. At the end i paid triple. Now, I am super piss out and will try to find out what happened. I want my money back!
author: Natalia N.

description:
This place is great!

I just ate here for the first time today with a coworker and had a great experience.  We were seated immediately, despite it being the lunch rush hour.  The place smells amazing!  As soon as you walk in it just reeks (in a good way!) of yummy Thai goodness!  Our service was fast and the food was great.  We both ordered the yellow curry and were no disappointed!  I'm a fan and will def go back.
author: Jen K.

description: The pumpkin curry is good but that's about it. Their other food is average and you can get better quality at Osha's. It's always crowded so you need a reservation.
author: Kat P.

description: I gave this place another chance since my friend was craving thai food. I told her no, but that was the closest place for thai. My before experience was gross. Gross customer service, gross food. Anyways, it has not changed, the water is not even cold, the waitress takes forever to bring me hot sauce. (Isn't the hot sauce suppose to be on the table anyways?) Now, the waitress doesn't even say "thank you" when we leave.  It's still a no go. Still giving us the check in the middle of eating! If you are big on being treated nicely, great customer service, and having and getting respect, don't go here!
author: Poison I.

description:
I ate here for the first time the other day. While not a fancy place, the staff was friendly and the food came quickly. I had ordered the Pad Thai which is my favorite Thai dish. The version they served had a really funky underlying flavor that I couldn't place, but also couldn't stand. My dinner companions tried it too and agreed that it tasted really weird so I ended up sending it back. I got the Pumpkin Curry instead which was really good. 

To their credit, when I left the kitchen staff asked for feedback on the Pad Thai and seemed to honestly want to improve their menu which really impressed me. Would definitely eat here again.
author: Deb M.

description:
MANGO CHICKEN TAP DANCING ON MY PALATE!!!!

This place is on Kearny and you can sometimes expect big suprises in small restaurants. It's always a toss up between Bankok's Best and Banana House, all the other thai restaurants next door are passed up. But I ate at Banana House first before Bankok's Best and I still come to Banana House more too. My coworkers and I would come here at least once every week or two. We stick to the picks we like. 

When you first walk in the waiters and waitresses great you and seat you down right away. I think they know we're regulars and seat us. For the longest we never really knew there was a downstairs. One time we were seated downstairs and I felt like I was in the basement. But usually we're seated on street-level by the window. The seats and tables suck. They're not comfortable. We get fast service and we can watch the cooks prepare our food. Their dishes are proportionate to the price you pay and the taste is SO GOOD. 

I love how they serve the dish with a scope of rice and salad, another cute bowl on the plate with the dish! It's so cute!

I've order a good handful of items off of their menu:
- satay
- fried calamari
- pad thai
- garlic pan
- some green noodle dish
- fried banana with icecream! (yum)

but my favorite is MANGO CHICKEN! I cannot get mango chicken anywhere close to how this place services it. I can go on a streak and eat this everyday for lunch. It's THAT good. Definately yummy and knocks me palate!
author: Jane A.

description:
Passed this place several times before deciding to try it. We only did takeout, so I cannot comment on service.

Tempted by the pad thai, as it my gauge for most Thai places, I decided to be healthier and went for something completely different: Duck Salad.

It was quite tasty, and despite its small size in appearance, quite filling. The salad was unique, and I would order it again. If I eat there again I would do a followup review, but overall it is an inexpensive, decent Thai lunch place.
author: Jordan C.

description:
The food was fine. Not great, but good for lunch. The atmosphere is more divey than I'd expect, but that was fine too. What really got me was the service. We had to stare (Intently) towards the kitchen to get a server to come over and take our order.

After waiting quite a while, one order came out and mine was no where to be found. After about five minutes I tried to flag someone down - which was quite a chore. By the time we got our food I had to eat quickly and get back to work, but not before the obstacles of getting a to go box, our check and our receipts. 

Thanks Banana House, but there are a lot of other (better) places to go spend my lunch money.
author: Ixchel F.

description:
My office ordered dinner here while working on a late night project. Due to said project, we absolutely could not leave our desks, even for dinner. This is where Banana House comes in, because pretty much all restaurants in the FiDi are closed at that hour, except for here and CPK. Thai food was majority's vote, and thai food is what we had for dinner.

Banana House gets +1 star for free delivery before 9:30PM and + 1 star for quick delivery service. However, they got my order wrong (I ordered Pad Kee Mao with chicken; they gave me tofu...okay) and while they were thoughtful enough to tape the straw opening of my thai iced tea to prevent spills, they forgot to include my straw. Food was decent enough, about expected, and thai iced tea was delicious - still sweet even when water diluted. Compared to my lunch at Bangkok Best, I'd say they're both about the same, food wise.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I've eaten at Banana House for lunch or dinner for several years, so I should probably weigh in.  

I've had better Thai food, and I've had much, MUCH worse.  Banana House is reliable.  It's open when I need it to be (lunch and early evenings), the food is okay, the service is okay, and it's cheap.  I like their pumpkin curry and their so-called "garlic pan" (I never did figure out the "pan" part) with chicken.  The latter will keep the vampires away from your door for days.  They do a barbecue chicken dish (take longer!) that's just a plate of boneless chicken thighs with a sweet/spicy sauce that I adore.  I like that they have brown rice available most of the time.

I like you very much, Banana House.  You're not the Ritz, but I don't always want the Ritz.  You're cheap and easy (like some folks I know), and you're open when I need you to be (like...oh, never mind).  I will continue to patronize you and continue to be happy that you're there for me in the FiDi.
author: Earline A.

description:
Busy little lunch spot.

I ordered the spicy catfish expecting a filet. It was actually cut up pieces of pan fried catfish which was pretty good, very spicy, but ultimately not what I thought I was ordering.

I like that each table has a number assigned to it and you go up and pay for "Table #2" or whatever, but it makes me wonder if anyone ever abuses the system...?

Service was pretty bad. I really needed some water after my spicy fish and had to wait 10 minutes before anyone came back to check on me. Meh.
author: Rachel L.

description: The calamari is wierd.  It's all batter.  The food is really greasy.  I don't think I need to elaborate.
author: Maria V.

description: Meh! Not the best Thai food place I've been to. Food is just about okay and the Thai iced tea was bad. I will not recommend this place, because of the more awesome restaurants around this very spot.
author: Saberi K.

description:
I hate to do this...if you know of another thai place then go there.  I only go here when it's really empty.  They're already really aloof, and not so nice, God forbid they put you in the moldy downstairs room during rush hour.  Get ready for cold chicken if that happens.  I'm sorry, I appreciate the businessman's venture and all and I'm a strict capitalist, but damn get it together.  And I love thai food.  I'd drink curry sauce if it would hydrate me.

thumbs down
author: Amir B.

description: I ordered here from Gopago and I will honestly say that this was my worst experience from any restaurant in San Francisco. Ordered - 15 minutes later, they messaged to say that my order was ready, so I walk over and show them my receipt. They find my receipt and take it to the kitchen, where they proceed to start preparing my order (Pad Won Soon). It took them 20 minutes to get me my order and four people who came after me received their orders (having waited 5-10 minutes) and left. This restaurant's staff is clearly not prepared for takeout orders - not to mention that their portions were also small.
author: Dexter L.

description: Of the two places on this block (the other is Bangkok Best), I definitely prefer Banana House.  The service is always very fast, and it's a great option for a quick sit-down lunch (a rare find in the neighborhood).  I got the mango chicken both times I ate there, and quite enjoyed it.  Nothing to write home about, but a solid option for a workday lunch.  There's also a big downstairs area so don't worry if it looks really crowded from the street!
author: Jessica R.

description:
3 stars average sounds about right for this place.
$10 for an order of pad thai. it was dark brown instead of the usual pink that i'm used to. not sure how that affects the taste, tbh.
it will fill you up probably, but there's not much meat compared to noodle. also my chicken was extremely dry so it wasn't that tasty anyway.
i was waiting at the front for my order and an employee brought it out but didn't give me napkins or any utensils, lol.
i work right nearby so if i wanted something quick and easy and were craving thai in particular i'd probably come again but it wasn't great at all, honestly.
author: Skinny L.

description:
I ordered the sweet & sour dish with chicken.  I can't speak for its authenticity, but I thought it was very good!  The food in general was good, and the portions were the perfect size for me (as in, they aren't super-large).

The only thing that got me was the prices.  Everything was just a dollar or two more than I preferred, and you had to pay extra to get rice.
author: Natalie H.

description: Oh hell yes.  I have always been slow to steer away from my usual choice of pumpkin curry but the Banana house has two options that are now going to be in my permanent rotation.  Mango curry and Fruit curry.  I had the mango and killed the whole thing in about four minutes.  The fruit curry sounds even better so I am gonna attack that next time around.
author: Dru P.

description:
Cheap Thai food. My friends love the soup named Broken Patroon (sp check?) but I found it very sour. Personal taste. I don't like the chicken satay with peanut sauce because it looks like sheets of eggs and there is no peanut in the sauce, bit like water mixed with peanut butter and call it a sauce... My friends thought she ate a piece of fried egg LOL... Fried rice with shrimp was quite nice with a hint of curry. The green curry with beef is not recommended because the sauce is too sweet for my taste and the beef, oh dear, did we order beef jerky? I like the papaya salad, I also ordered egg pancake because I were at one point confused that with the egg pancake I had in some Korean restaurant haha. My bad. So, everybody had a bit of egg omlette for dinner. 

Service is 5 stars. The waitress was friendly and easy going and know when to come to our table. When I wanted to add the egg pancake order I were just thinking of walk over to the counter where she stood chatting with her coworker. However, as soon as she saw me stood up holding the menu she stopped talking with her coworker and quickly come round to our table to take my order. 

Customers come in twos and groups. I think this place is great for a quick meal. Maybe we could come back for other dishes if we happened to be in the neighbourhood.
author: Bella A.

description:
Part of knowing where to eat is figuring out which places are sit down vs. take out places.  Banana House is definitely the latter.  I wouldn't take my boss or client here, nor would I come here to propose or take my mom out for her birthday.

But I do come here for a quick take out meal while working late in the office.  It's quick, relatively cheap and relatively good (albeit a touch greasy).  

Quick observations: 
1.  For some reason, they don't serve brown or jasmine rice.
2.  Their open for Sunday dinner which is helpful if one's stuck working over the weekend.
author: David A.

description:
As is said in other reviews, it's a madhouse around the lunch hour and there is really no place to wait for your food if you're ordering to-go. The menu is large and vegetarian selections are noted for you.

I had the Mango Curry with Tofu. Portion size was excellent for FiDi lunch, large enough to satiate but not too much. Flavor was good and curry seemed well balanced, my only complaint is that the mango chunks are ENORMOUS compared to the size of the other ingredients.

+1 for being staffed by actual Thais. A good, solid choice for reasonably quick lunch in the area.
author: Tom M.

description: Good, quick service. Tasty food and reasonable price. In the Finanical District, Chinatown area, Banana House is a good option (and costs less than the "fancy" chain Thai restaurant that has bastardized Thai food and has much higher prices).
author: Flynt I.

description: Pretty good place for Thai food in the Financial District. We went there because it seemed to be the only decent non-Chinese place open for dinner in that area. The owners were very friendly. Food was very tasty and fast. You could see them cooking it in the wok in the kitchen, which was interesting to watch. A bit pricy, but quite understandable for that location. The Tom Kha soup was delicious.
author: Justin H.

description: Stumbled upon this gem when the restaurant across the way couldn't seat us. Went with a group of 8 people. Everyone loved what they got. I got the tofu satay appetizer. Best peanut sauce I've had. Would go back! Again and again.
author: Melissa L.

description:
How can you not love this place for a cheap lunch?

The Pad Ke Mao with Tofu is awesome.
author: Matthew R.

description: Decent Thai food. Cant expect that much considering the area. Prices are decent for the togo buffet style.
author: T L.

description: My boyfriend and I were in downtown and trying to find a good place to eat. We searched Yelp and Banana House won our votes. I had the Pad Thai and it was pretty good. But what I really enjoyed about the place was its service. The waitresses were really nice and honest. I wanted to have mango sticky rice for dessert, but she said their mangos aren't very good so she suggested I don't order it.
author: Samantha G.

description: I ordered Spaghetti Kee Mao to go - the restaurant itself looks like well organized and the order was first come first served - I received my order  timely fashion.  When my order arrived it looked pretty decent as described on the menu - it was delicious but a little on spicy side - its not perfect but well above average and prices are cheap.  Highly recommended.  I should have added rice to go...definitely next time.
author: Lar G.

description:
I've been here maybe three times spaced out months at a time.  Twice I got the mango chicken curry and the other time i got some noodle thing which obviously didn't leave much of an impression on me.

The mango curry was full of flavor.  After an hour or two I did start to get really thirsty so my guess is the salt helped the flavor along.  Anyway, the chicken in the curry was tender and there was a good amount.  The mango pieces were good too.  Overall I really like the mango curry - obviously since i remembered liking it enough to get it again.  Anyhoo, for the financial district the pricing is about the same.  The portion is a little smaller than I'd like it to be.  I did run out of rice before I finished the curry but I am pretty heavy on the carbs so I guess that could just be me.


we got there a little before 12 and got seated right away. there were a few more tables open but i imagine they fill up quickly.  the service was quick.  our table was oriented sorta weird but it was alright.  I'd come here again if I felt like thai curry.  It wasnt spectacular but it did the trick.
author: S T.

description:
I'm upgrading this to five stars because it is so consistently good in quality and delivery,   Really dependable.


Wow, really good especially for the money.

I order a lot of delivery via eat24 and I tried Banana house a few times now.
The Masaman beef curry is AWESOME.
The Yum Nuer is very good.
The Larb Gai is good.
The Tom Kha Gai is bland and watery.  
(What is it about SF that you can't find good Tom Kha anywhere?)  Hit SJ or SoCal for that.

So, there are enough really good things here that I'll keep ordering.  Prices are BELOW MARKET.
author: erin b.

description:
I had a Chicken Yang Dang and it was spicy & nice.
My girlfriend had a Mango Curry with Prawns. That wasn't so good.

Overall, it's a good Lunch place.
I recommend it and would myself go there again.
author: Bhagya D.

description:
We came here after visiting some art galleries, and were quite hungry after drinking a bunch of free wine. We were also looking for something reasonably priced, which can be somewhat difficult to find north of Market street.

One of the members of my group strongly advocated for this place, so we sat down. A bunch of people got the Thai Iced Teas, which looked good, but I stuck with water.

The menu has pretty much all of the Thai foods that you could want. Everything comes with beef, chicken, pork, or tofu. I'm not eating a lot of meat these days, and happen to be allergic to tofu, so I actually went for the fried rice, which had the option of pineapple.

The pineapple actually went pretty well with the fried rice. It also had cucumber, tomato, and a lot of green onion. Oh, and of course egg. An hour later, my breath still smells like green onion. Overall, the food was solid if unexceptional.

The decor was plain but clean, and the service was fairly good. They split up our checks without us asking - we had a party of seven people, and they added a gratuity to that. My meal came to $10 all inclusive, which seemed a bit stiff for fried rice, but it wasn't a complete ripoff.

Overall, not a bad place to go. Decent food that isn't horribly expensive and is edible.
author: Dana L.

description:
Up in SF for a (successful!) meeting, I stopped into this restaurant on Kearny.  It is a tiny place, jam-packed with customers.  I was in search of some healthy-ish Thai food.  I found the Thai salad, which is a chopped salad served with boiled chicken and peanut sauce on the side.  Conclusion:  Thai Salad:  healthy for sure.  A bit boring for sure.  

I looked around at the other dishes, and they looked reasonable.  Some folks were sweating profusely, so the hot food must be hot.  Not sure.  I just had cold veggies with a tiny bit of peanut sauce (I held back).  I might give it a higher rating if I ate something better...
author: Patrick G.

description:
I hate to do this, it is my first one star review but literally this was the worst Thai Food I have ever eaten and there was nothing redeeming about the place. 

I should have been tipped off after sitting down and then sauntering to the bathroom that I saw not one but two microwaves on my trip but I didn't think much of it at the time. 

I ordered the Pad See Ew and the meat was extremely overcooked and the flavor of the noodles was way to sweet. 

My group ordered Tom Kha to start and it was overcooked and under flavored and we ordered Thai spring rolls, instead of the usual sticky-rice-paper clear wrapping they were wrapped in some cheap knock-off paper and tasted like it. 

The worst part was the vegetables - they were mealy and gross - clearly not ripe or even in season, please do yourself a favor and do not go to this place.
author: Marissa C.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Thai food and have once again begun my never-ending search to find the best Thai restaurant within 20 miles.

Banana House doesn't take that honor, but I would definitely go back. Menu has some interesting options you don't always see, and I was very happy with Basil / Octopus curry. My wife's yellow curry was a little less exciting but still good enough.
author: Mark F.

description: No Food, no stars.  We were seated promptly and then no one came over to take our order or give us some water and utensils.  Nothing for 10 minutes!  So we left went over to a great middle eastern food place a few doors down called Balade Cafe.  We ordered and we were eating in about 5 minutes.  True.
author: James T.

description: Nothing fancy that's for sure but decent, good, fresh food. The mango curry was very good. Service was good as well. Looked like a lot of folks ordered to go."
author: Gail M.

description:
Not good. I read the other reviews but went in with an open mind to try some appetizers and will not be returning.

Shrimp Bolster (deep-fried prawns rolls with S&S sweet chile sauce, $7.95):  Yuck, shrimp was squishy and was sliced in half - so you don't even get whole prawns! Worse yet, the shrimp was not "de-veined" - meaning there were giant turds in each one of them. Really disgusting. I order the same things from Chai Yo on Polk, or Koh-Samui on Brannan and they're clean, crispy, and poop-free. Do some people not mind eating shrimp poop??

Tom Kha Gai (coconut milk soup, vegetarian-style, $6.95): There were barely any vegetables in it aside from 3 or so mushrooms, some canned baby corn, two tomato slices, and some unhealthy/crinkled and wilted lettuce. The lettuce had speckles on the stalk area that looked like some sort of plant disease.

In all, a very expensive lunch and I threw most of it away.
author: Heidi G.

description: After a meeting with a client, my co-worker and I were standing in front of the client's building discussing where to have lunch.  Someone overheard us saying we wouldn't mind some Thai food.  This stranger piped up and said we should walk down the street and less than a block away on the right was a really good Thai restaurant.  Well, I'm not sure if we went to the one he was recommending, but Banana House was a disappointment.  The food was tolerable, but nothing special.  Service was also just tolerable.  The interior was dingy and not very clean.  We were seated downstairs, which was claustrophobic.  I definitely would have checked Yelp first if I had had an Internet-enabled mobile device with me that day!
author: Sherri C.

description:
Banana House has risen to the occasion many times for group lunches with my co-workers.  It is one of the few places we have found in the financial district that can ALWAYS accomodate our group of 10, without any wait.  The downstairs seating area is their secret weapon in being able to do this.

I really have no complaints about Banana House.  The food is pretty good, and the prices are reasonable.  The service is decent, although their kitchen seems to be on the smaller side because we are usually served two plates at a time, every couple minutes or so, until the entire group is served.  It takes a little while, but they have been very consistent over our many visits.

For entrees, I'd recommend the Yum Talay "Salad."  It's a refreshing salad of silver noodles and a tangy chili/lime dressing, served with pieces of calamari, mussels, and prawns.  I've also enjoyed the Chicken Cashew Nuts, as well as the standard Chicken Pad Thai.  An added bonus is when they play old episodes of Mr. Bean on the downstairs television.
author: Tim N.

description: We were walking around on a Saturday and this was one of the only restaurants open on a weekend, so it already gets an extra star.  Overall the food was decent.  I had the special, mango fried rice and everything was really good.  I tried the sweet and sour and it was fairly boring and disappointing.  The sweet and sour gets 2 stars and mango fried rice gets 4, so that is the 3 star total.  The place itself seems a little dirty and run down, but what are you going to do when you are starving and everything else is closed.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
Cons: 
Bland - NOT what Thai food should taste like.
The little green card posted next to the door... or what's written on it.

Pros: 
Fast, cheap (relatively).
Close to work!

Saves me time on my one-hour lunch break, but I was expecting a little more. Okay, maybe a lot more. I'm Indonesian and thus crave Thai food a lot (as close as it gets to my culture around FiDi), but I don't think that's even enough to make me come back here, judging only from taste. 

I know I have a weak stomach and immune system, so I won't assume this is their fault, but I did get stomach ache and go to the bathroom a lot after this lunch... ... ...
author: Cynthia T.

description:
*sigh* 

jipped.

pretty sure the mango chicken curry i ordered was supposed to have more than just mango, chicken and curry. otherwise, i wouldn't have ordered it.

looked to my left. my friend had bell peppers & zucchinis in her pumpkin chicken curry. looked across. my friend had basils & beans in her pangang tofu curry. looked at mine again. the mango & chicken swam in a bowl of loneliness.

don't know what compelled me to sit quietly and not mention it to the waitress. maybe i didn't care for the food. possibly. maybe i wanted to wait til i'm back at the office to shed my tears. probably not.

food was mediocre. the mango was too ripe, and therefore, became too soft after being cooked. the curry lacked heat & flavor. 

slow service too.
author: Marti L.

description:
This little colorful Thai restaurant on busy Kearny street is always bustling with people. But don't be deceived, they have a downstairs as well so getting seated is usually not an issue or as low as a 5 min wait. I like to sit at one of the little tables out front when the weather is nice. 

After being seated is when the wait usually comes, even though they have a lot of servers, you usually have to wait 10-15 before they take your order. 

They have a great menu with your traditional appetizers like satay and spring rolls and new items like Thai sausage. I usually get the pad see ew noodles with steamed tofu and it is pretty delicious. They have a large variety of curries if you're into that. 

I love their mango with sticky rice dessert. It is super yummy! 

I've also been getting to-go and the wait is usually 10-15 min.
author: Gladys C.

description: I got their Papaya salad for lunch today. It was super liquidy. It had lumps of sugar or something like that. The lettuce was soggy(ew!). The shrimp tasted a little stale. The salad was also very stinky. I have a cup of cinnamon tea on my desk to get rid of that smell.
author: Fashfre C.

description: Ew. The people are nice but the food is disgusting. I lived in Thailand for a while and am a huge Thai food fan - this is not good Thai food. Ordered the pad se ew - and it was burnt. Pieces of black char on the noodles and veggies. The summer rolls were literally pieces of tofu in this weird rice roll that was kind of grainy - not the typical rice wrap you'd see for summer rolls. Disgusting, I couldn't even eat it. And they charged me $3 extra for shrimp ($11 for summer rolls when you can get it for $6-7 anywhere else with shrimp included). They forgot to give me the rice with the pad ka prow....the only thing that was good (very good) was the mango with sticky rice.
author: anjali s.

description:
I ordered the Tofu Pad Thai from here the other night while staying late at work. Let me start off by saying my office is one block away and that it took about an hour to deliver. We had to call once to find out what was taking so long before it arrived. 

To keep the story short, WORST Pad Thai I have tried. It was dry, the noodles were completely stuck together and it had no flavor. That was just my dish. My other coworkers who ordered there food also complained their food was awful. One coworker order the curry and it didn't even come with rice!
author: Stephen D.

description:
Banana House...hmmm...sounded like an all-male nude revue to me. I thought maybe Boy was going to leave me here with a stack of $1 bills and come back for me when the show was over. Unfortunately, it's just a lunch place in the fidi. 

Fortunately, the food is damn yummy. Even my anemic-looking mound of boiled chicken breast (they *do* have breasts...just no bananas) over iceberg lettuce with limp tomatoes and too much cucumber was magically brought to life with a delicious peanut sauce dressing. It was gone in about 5 minutes. It was A LOT of chicken for around $7. Boy's pad ka somethingorother with wide noodles and burning hot spices was really good too, if a little small for $8. 

Unfortunately, it took about 25 minutes to get our food (this is not a fancy establishment and therefore I had guessed it would be a little faster). 

Fortunately, there is ample seating and the there was no wait to sit at a big window table during the fidi lunch rush.

Unfortunately, for $20 we could have had two tomato soups in puff pastry at Jeanty at Jack's and it probably would have come faster too.

I may do take out from here in the future- they have a pumpkin curry I'm dying to try. As it stands, though, I really think this block could use an all-male nude revue a lot more than it could use another Thai restaurant. They wouldn't even need to change the name...Just a suggestion...
author: Autumn K.

description:
DO NOT GO!!!
I was really tired and hungry the other day, so I randomly picked this restaurant on the street. My sister tried to stop me, but I was too tired to listen, so I just went in without looking at the menu outside. 
we both ordered ice thai tea, and my sister tried to tell them to put less sugar, but the waitress said "they are already made.". SO here they come the sweetest ice thai tea I have ever tasted...
well I thought the food may not be that bad, so I ordered my favorite thai dish, which is roast duck fried rice. But I was really really disappointed!!!the rice was a mess..and the egg was not combined with the rice, as well as the duck...LOL 
Man, how is that considered Fried Rice???

I think this restaurant has no heart, no passion for food!!!
author: Christy Y.

description:
Banana House needs a coat of paint; It seems like what was once a very modern, stylish restaurant has been weathered by years of waiters running back and forth, and office workers sitting down for a quick lunch, or waiting to be seated, or waiting for a take out order. Mostly doing a lot of waiting.

See, compared to many of the lunch spots in the area, Banana House is painfully slow; We waited around 25 minutes between ordering and eating, and it's even worse when your table is right by the entrance to the kitchen area and the waitresses walk by you with plate after plate of food. They almost appear to want to say to you "Check out this steaming plate of Pra Ram Chicken that someone else is going to enjoy! And I wonder who's gonna get this delicious looking Pad Thai? Not you! Sorry!"

When your food finally arrives, you may find that they make a pretty good plate of Pad Kee Mao, plenty spicy and a less greasy than you'll find at a lot of places. The basic chicken salad isn't anything out of the ordinary, except that they make a tasty peanut salad dressing. 

I could be persuaded to come here again. There aren't lots of Thai options down this way, and Banana House has a pretty extensive menu (though missing the Gaeng Ped that I had there on a Saturday two or three years ago.) Try to miss the lunch rush.
author: matthew r.

description:
The food is very tasty and well spiced, portions were good, the menu is extensive and they have the best desert on earth - Mango and Sticky Rice.

In short, If I have a hankering for good Thai again and I'm in the Financial District I'll head back.
author: Todd E.

description:
There is nothing better than a good Thai restaurant close to work or home.  Sadly, I'm still looking for one.

You'd think that if the Banana House folks were veg-savvy enough to offer veggie versions of many dishes, and ask if egg was OK in my Pad Thai, they'd know not to add fish sauce.  But they didn't.  Ick.  

Greasy + fishy = queasy afternoon.  Ick ick.

I'll give them another try and see how the pumpkin curry and brown rice fare, but I have to put some time between my tummy and the BH for a while.
author: Andi T.

description:
I am not a Thai food connoisseur... I just know at some places I like it more than others.  I like it a lot here.  I almost always stick to the soup, because they have one that I absolutely love.  If I feel crazy, I'll get the mango and sticky rice for dessert, which happens to be my favorite dessert in the entire world.

I'm not one to care about fancy decor, but even I noticed the ambiance here is naught.  Just a simple coat of paint could make a world of difference.

The service is generally fast, though, to be fair, I've never been here during a busy time.  I live in my own time zone, so I tend to get hungry at odd times.  Sometimes the staff isn't terribly attentive, but they have always been polite.

Overall, it's conveniently located,  fairly priced, and I really do love that soup.
author: Krystal K.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy I've got Thai in my tummy!!!!!

Today I met my noodle-caboodle here for a mid-week alcohol free adventure.  We got a quick chance to kvetch about our jobs over curry goodness.  The amount of food was just about right.  I felt full, but not like I was going to explode.  It was $22 for 2 lunch specials and 2 diet cokes - before tip..

FYI - The tables are close together, so this is not a good place to do any insider trading.  But we did learn that the girl at the table next to us had a real Cartier watch on, and the girl with her had a similar fake one at home.
author: Nikki c.

description:
This place is solid and inexpensive.  And, having sampled pumpkin curry at many Thai restaurants, I think the pumpkin curry at Banana is, well, solid (there's that word again).  I always order the pumpkin curry with tofu, because frying tofu is something I think they do especially well at this establishment; it's perfectly braised and tender with a thin golden skin.  

Additional solid menu items include: spicy catfish (actually spicy!), pad thai, pad see u, and, as mentioned above, the pumpkin curry.  I'm curious about the fried eggplant and the papaya salad, but I've somehow not gotten around to trying these things, though I'm sure I will since this place is on my lunch venue circuit.  That tells you something there.

The appetizers are not worth it here from my experience- they're basically a selection of things straight from the freezer to the fry basket, and despite the dexterity shown with the tofu, the fried calamari and fried corn patty appetizers (more patty than corn) are seriously OILY, a sensation I think caused by the oil not being hot enough during the frying.  And this is coming from a person that likes oily things.  Really.

In closing I'd just like to say that this is a satisfactory lunch time eating experience.  It is not, however, THAI FOOD TO DIE FOR, nor is it as good as Osha.  That being said, you do get what you pay for here, and as long as you aren't expecting a mind-blowing experience, but instead some solid grubbing, then you'll be happy dining here.
author: Chalk A.

description: Nice place to go for lunch in the Financial District area.  The food is good but nothing stands out amazingly.  The staff is nice and the service is pretty quick for it being really busy at lunch hours.  Overall not bad, try this place out.
author: Jesse C.

description:
This place has good honest well-priced Thai food. That said I don't have anything very interesting to say. My boss did get some avocado in her curry.

They didn't tell me they were out of brown rice until they brought my order to the table. Their duck in red curry with pineapple, peppers and basil is spicy good.

I guess I have no business writing a review of this place tonight.
I did not like the iceburg lettuce with sweet peanut sauce on it. Blech.

Update: I apologize for this boring uninformative review. The truth is, I'm so sick of Thai food I wouldn't care if I never saw it again.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
My co-worker Nate A. is the poster child for sales.  Young, ambitious and ripe for the picking, this self-starter has managed to crush it his first two quarters on the job.  However, he is also a self-confessed emotional eater...which is awesome for me because he always comes into the office with new grub.  Now he NEVER shares his meals, but he will tell me where he bought it so that I too can lean on a stress-induced food crutch.  

One particular doozey of a morning, he decides to order pad Thai at 10 a.m.  It was huge.  It was aromatic.  Did he share it with me?  No....but I did trot right up to Banana House to get some for myself.  I ordered before lunch hours, so the food was ready in about 15.  I then proceeded to eat delicious chicken pad Thai for the next day and a half due to all the leftovers. 

Decent for takeout, gets pretty busy during lunch, dine-in questionable....
author: Kerry D.

description:
Four a lunch spot, I give Banana House 4 stars.

Good size portion for the price, fresh ingredients - the veggies in my Pad Kee Mao (spicy pan fried rice noodle with broccoli tomato, basil and bell pepper with chicken or tofu) - retained a good crunch.

Check out their weekday lunch specials - for curries or Banana House Plates, you get a side of Rice, Fried Wonton, and Thai Salad.

Service is friendly.  The inside is a bit cramped, but good for those cold SF days.  They have a few tables outside for those nice golden ones.
author: Cathy K.

description:
I felt compelled to write about this place affter just one visit.  My friends and I were really hungry and all I wanted was some simple pad see ew.  I just wanted something fast and I wasn't looking for the best pad see ew ever.  

First of all, service was not good.  Not everyone was hungry so not everyone ordered dinner and the waitress was extremely mean about it.  Not cool.  Even throughout dinner, service was poor and the waitresses were rude.

Second, the food was terrible.  Almost everything had too much sauce, and that was true for the pad see ew.  It was just really thick and saucy that you couldn't even taste the underlying food.

Overall, it gets two stars for poor service and poor food.  Not recommended.
author: Aron L.

description:
I came here by "accident" when I attempted to go to Muracci's next door, but they were FRIGGIN CLOSED this whole week for thanksgiving (understandable, but hmph, disappointing still) anyways -- I had a red curry w/chicken, pretty standard and all, but still good, good enough I might come back (even after reading the cockroach comment/review? possibly maybe..) 

the staff was pretty nice and accommodated to my request to replace bamboo shoots (hate those things!) with broccoli instead.  I asked for spicy but it was more mild for my taste.. guess I have to say EXTRA spicy next time..
author: Jennie L.

description:
This is not one of my favorite places, but I always give it a chance. I figured, I might get lucky one day . But truth be told. It really doesn't do much for me. Of course, that is just my humble opinion. 

There are other options out there for lunch, this certainly is not one I recommend. It is just ok and leaves me wishing I would had gone elsewhere. My main complaint is that it just feels too greasy, soupy... I can't put my finger on it... but the consistency is just not right with the sauces. And from the looks of the other reviews on here... it isn't just me. Hopefully they will work on it and make it all better. Places like this make me miss the dungeon on Bush and Kearny (Damn the fire!)!
author: Amelia M.

description: LOVE the pad see ew with chicken! Best I have had so far :) Im so hooked Im going today!
author: Stefanie M.

description:
Great lunch menu. Big portions at cheap prices. 

I went with the yellow curry with chicken and tofu over rice. It was PERFECT. That with a little salad and thai iced tea all for $10. Standard lunch price, but very very yummy!
author: Jen D.

description:
Banana House is a staple of my financial district diet.  There have been periods of time when I ate four meals a week here.

All the curries I've tried are great.  I recommend getting the combo meal version of anything, as the salad, spring rolls and thai iced tea make a great compliment to the main courses.  The Salmon Curry is delectable; big chunks of salmon and avocado make it feel like one of the healthiest things I've ever consumed.

Banana House is not particularly fancy, but it is delicious.  I wouldn't take a date here, if I had a date, but for workweek lunch or even dinner, it is Highly Recommended.  I'm a known repeat offender at the Banana House.
author: Oliver N.

description:
This is one bustling lunch spot!  But when I got here there was a table available and service was prompt.  Ordered the spicy eggplant with chicken and it was pretty good - a balanced, spicy sweet sauce with chunks of eggplant and tender slices of chicken.  The heat came from green chilies and the sweet came from sugar in the stir fry sauce and from slices of red bell pepper.  The steamed rice was okay, but I got a heaping portion.  And the side salad had a good peanut dressing that wasn't too sweet or overpowering.

I've been here with coworkers before and had green curry which was also pretty good.   

Three stars for being a good, inexpensive and quick Thai lunch place.  I've had better flavors, but then again I've also had worse.  Banana House is alright.
author: Eileen P.

description:
Meh. That about sums up my experience here. Came in on Monday and since i was dining alone was put in a corner facing a wall. Took the servers about 10 minutes to realize I was there... almost walked out. Ordered the lunch special. Salad was good. Had green beans with chicken but was so spicy I almost couldn't eat it.

Does okay in a pinch but... I thought 10.00 was a little steep for that.
author: laura f.

description:
Came here for lunch for a work thing.  It's not gourmet Thai by any means, but it's fast.   Our server was funny and was quick to respond to jokes.  I like that.  One extra star for her.

Various orders all around, so I will only speak of my Yellow Chicken Curry and my co-worker's Chicken Pad See Ew.  Two of my favorites in any Thai restaurant.  I won't say it was the best I've ever had, but it was good.  My curry had lots of juicy chicken and it was spicy !  WHEW!  Pad See Ew was loaded with chicken and veggies. 

It's a little out of my  way for a quick lunch, so you won't find me there too often.  But if you're in the area, I would recommend trying it.
author: Denise M.

description:
Came here for lunch today....just a note to everyone, during the lunch hour this place is packed and the wait for a table isnt that bad but dont expect to do anything else after eating other then heading back to the office.

Anyhow, so Wilson, Alex and I waited about 5-10min at most for a table which wasnt too bad during this hectic time of lunch. The waitress gave us our menus and noticed how they had a nice lunch special in fine print at the bottom of the menu. The funny thing is that they have a big box on the menu for a jasmin special (i think thats what it is called) that you add on for 3.50 or so. The lunch special comes with rice and a small salad added to your order so this will technically be the bang for your buck.

I had the yellow curry with chicken, Wilson had the red curry with beef and avocado and Alex had a chicken with rice noodle. Overall its pretty good. The yellow curry wasnt too salty or heavy and Wilson seemed to enjoy the red curry quite much. Not so sure how Alex enjoyed his food but he seemed satisfied and finished the entire dish.  Banana House gives you a good amount of food so you are not too full and wont fall into a food coma at work.

Overall we all paid about 10 bucks a head which isnt too shabby and it seems to be the norm around these parts of town during lunch anyhow.
author: phillip w.

description: Decent service and moderate prices keep me coming back to this place. Banana House is one of my go-to lunch spots in the Financial District.  It has swift service so you can easily get in and out in less than an hour. The food here is warm and comforting though certainly not the best Thai that SF has to offer.
author: Jamie A.

description:
My stomach:  I'm in the mood for noodles, J.
Me:  Uh, alright, S.  Hmm...  Can I interest you with a visit to Banana House?  And can we invite a real friend? 
My stomach:  O-kay...(begrudgingly tags along).
1 hour later...

Me:  Well, stomach.  How was the meal? Did you enjoy the company?
Stomach:  Silence, with the occasional digestive gurgling.
Me: I guess that means she's full, happy...and sleeping.  

Me:  I've been to Banana House a few times already, each time really enjoying my meal.  This time my stomach wanted Pad See Ew which was incredibly alive with fresh thick rice noodles & broccoli.  But ya gotta like fish sauce & the sweetness.  And for a little extra moolah, you can overindulge in some egg rolls, Thai ice tea & rice.  I don't quite get that combo though...

My stomach and I will return here again, when we've got hankerings for Thai.  Bring a friend or your stomach at least.
author: Jen L.

description:
My coworker's favorite - Mango Curry with Chicken.  

I don't have a favorite here.. I try out bunch of stuff:

Spicy catfish - S-P-I-C-Y!  no joke!  Hecka tasty tho
Yellow Curry - Big portion.  Pretty good.  Not too special however.
Pad Thai with Prawns - T-A-S-T-Y with big prawns.  Very generous.
Pineapple Fried Rice - yum!

Next time imma try the House Yellow Curry fried rice with.... i think it said raisin there... hmmm interesting....
author: Gigi T.

description:
I went here for takeout at lunch today.  For a value lunch it was great!  I had the pad see ew with tofu and have to say i was pleasantly surprised!  The broccoli and carrots were not overdone and the tofu was soft.  The portion was perfect, not too much.
Definitely crowded at lunch time and not much atmosphere, but excellent for takeout.
author: lena m.

description:
I'm a fan of Thai food, and this place is one of the best.  The prices and the food are amazing, especially for how much you get.  The Gang Dang is the perfect amount of spicy, and their lunch special includes rice and a Thai Salad as well, so you can't go wrong for under $10!

If you have to grab lunch in the Financial District, definitely check this place out.
author: Mike M.

description: this place is a DUMP.  it constantly smells like bleach or piss and if you sit downstairs it is like a dungeon.  two thai places around fidi closed and sucks that this place is open now.  always check your credit card statements because they double charged me.  place is totally shady.
author: F S.

description: This place is a regular favorite for my coworkers.  I find it alright.  Nothing amazing, but I'll still go there with them.  If you can try to sit upstairs.  Downstairs is dark and not as nice.
author: Brian G.

description:
Whatever I tried there was good! I don't eat spicy foods and they always made it very mild for me and i was able to enjoy it. I work in the neighborhood and I come there quite often (especially if I go shopping at the Loehmann's near by) :-)))))

I don't like their downstairs floor; it's stuffy and just not good! They couldn't fit a party of 6 at the top floor and we had to sit downstairs and I couldn't wait to get out. 

Their menu has some perfect choices and the service at Banana House is excellent. Not once I had to wait for my to-go more than 10min and it was well prepared and nicely packed. 

Banana House here I come...:-)
author: Katja S.

description: They have a room downstairs as well and they accommodated 9 of us for lunch. The service was pretty fast and the food was good, but nothing outstanding.
author: Yoko S.

description:
When a mango curry costs 7.95 plus tax I expect the taste, portion, or something to match the price. It tasted ok, but the portion was so small. Luckily I came in during lunch time which at least it meant the entree came with a tiny scoop of rice and some salad otherwise I think I would have had a heart attack., but it still was ridiculously EXPENSIVE! 

To top it off, I had a piece of plastic in my rice. I told the waitress. She took the piece from me, said ok and than walked off. Uh, not even a sorry? Thanks, it made me really want to come back again. Not!
author: Erica B.

description: I tried the string beans with chicken lunch plate today and it was too spicy and too salty. I probably just ordered the wrong thing because it was pretty crowded during lunch and the service was fast.
author: Helen Y.

description:
They serve pumpkin curry! YAY!
The entrees come with a small salad. Neat!
Most of their veggies are unripe and taste like cardboard. BOOOOOO...
author: Dave M.

description:
Pumpkin Curry - bland, yet overly greasy. There was an inch of oil floating on top.

Eggplant with chicken - bland yet overly greasy.

Pad Thai - overly sweet.
