Papaya salad - overly sweet, but still satisfying.

In terms of Thai food in the city, Banana House gets 1.5 stars. They get an extra 1.5 stars for being the only Thai place that delivers to my office (essential for those days when I forget to order dinner through our service and it's raining or I'm too lazy too pick up takeout from Golden Star). The food may suck, but it's sucky food that's DELIVERED, and between having bad food and having no food, my stomach would rather have bad food (although my taste buds would rather have no food).
author: Deb I.

description:
I just finished eating my take out from this place.  I have never had "spring rolls" like this.  It was almost like they were wrapped in tortilla or a lavash or something, with barely anything on the inside.  That was pretty much really gross, and super disappointing since the place I really wanted food from (but was closed) has pumpkin and mint in their spring rolls.  
I also got a green curry, it was standard, nothing that spectacular, but not as gross as the wrap rolls.  oh and the rolls had a pile of egg on top.  gross.
author: Katherine K.

description:
THIS PLACE SUCKS.
We just ordered 4 lunch entrees to be delivered to the office, spent over $45, and not only were the orders totally incorrect, but also the food was super spicey, rather than MILD, which we specified several times when the order was placed.  

I tried for 20 minutes to get someone on the telephone, and when i finally did the woman did not speak English, and had the nerve to ask me to call back when they were less busy.  I refused and told her the issue and so I "held".

The manager or whomever got on the phone and asked me to COME IN to return the food.  I told him it was not an option, since we had it delivered in the first place.  He asked me to call back at 3 when they are less busy.  I refused to do this, as well, so he said he could not help me.  I told him that if he did not either 1) get our orders right or 2) compensate us now, or I will tell everyone I know to not eat there.  

He finally took my telephone number to "call me back" 4xs--yes!  4 times before he got the number right.  This place might as well have rats, because not only am I never ordering from there again, but also I am spreading this story like the plague.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Great place for Thai during the week.  It's close to work, and better than the other place which is just a couple of doors down.  However, the cooking is just okay.  You can definitely find better Thai food somewhere else in the city.  

This place gets my "3" based on authenticity (it's staffed by Thais), price (moderate) and location.
author: Rod '.

description:
See my review of "Bangkok Best"

This restaurant is basically the same restaurant, they share the same chefs, same servants and etc.  The decor is just different between places and they're only less than a half block away from eachother.

I highly recommend though, if you're looking for some good and inexpensive Thai.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I love that the wait staff here pays such close attention to the state of my water glass, or maybe that was just today.  I drink a lot of water.

I was all set to order my gang panang - combo style with my thai iced coffee, veggie spring rolls, and salad (overly drenched with warm (ew!) chunky peanut butter?), but my companion was adamant that Thai food is ALWAYS served family style, that if it wasn't family style that was like saying I like to eat my steak on the ceiling...  I argued that this was a FIDI lunch spot and maybe people want to eat their own food, and not pine over a dearth of pad see ew that Bob from accounting just shoveled on to his own plate, leaving you a few flat noodles and a sprig of broccoli.  

So I acquiesced and we ordered the pad thai, and the gang panang.  The gang panang was pleasantly spicy, but skimped on oversized chunks of avocado and chicken.  The pad thai on the other hand was overpowered by someone's heavy hand with the fish sauce.  I couldn't stomach it.  You do realize how fish sauce comes into existence right?

I've had much better thai, but it wasn't greasy and is reasonable and fast.  It'll do in a pinch for lunch, if you twist my arm.
author: Ryan G.

description:
One of the great things about my life is that I've always been surrounded by people who are amazingly smart, shockingly talented, and occasionally even really nice.  It's all really more than a simple cowboy lawyer ought to be able to ask for.  Case in point: in law school, I met a woman who was an Ivy League grad, former political science professor, and now a classmate.  And she worked with me in the hallowed halls of the DOJ (local division), trying to make the world a better place.  And she LOVED Thai food.  They serve a lot of that in Boston, apparently, not so much back where I come from.  She made it her personal mission to educate me about the wonders of Thai food, and in the course of several dozen lunches, I became a fan.  We had our last Thai lunch when she was amazingly pregnant, and before I moved (never to see her again), I got to meet her daughter, who was at that time 5, and who apparently loved Thai food as well, likely from all the neonatal doses ingested by her mother in my presence.

By the way, that story makes me feel old just telling it.

My standard for measuring Thai food is the duck curry.  If the restaurant doesn't have it, or has only mock duck, I'm dubious right out of the gate.  Banana House has a great duck curry, and from that I deduce that they have other great foods, although I've never had anything else, because when you can have great duck curry, why have anything else?

And it is the blessing (and curse) of the particular functioning of my memory that every time I sit down to a big bowl of delicious duck curry, I think about Robyn, and I wonder how big her daughter is now, and I remember where I was in my life when we first ate duck curry together.  I don't know whether such unshakable memories are a blessing, a curse, or both, but I have thousands of them.

Not all associated with duck curry, though.

Ben P: Free story with every review.
author: Ben P.

description:
The waitresses were nice.  We surprised them during a slow time of day(evening-dinner) with a group of 22 so it's kind of fair that the food didn't come out all at the same time or anything, but....

There was plastic in my food. Like plastic wrap that had gotten cooked.
My vegetarian friend got chicken.
Even beyond the plastic, my standard pad see ew was disgusting tasting.

I'll give it another chance because I've heard so many good things about the place, and the staff was nice, but not anytime soon.
author: Heidi P.

description:
Gets very crowded during peak lunch time but thats true for pretty much any good place. They have this dish called Traffic Jam which gives you multiple curries (I think 3) in one entree. Its very good.
I like the food here but some how I feel pretty much everything tastes the same.
author: Homer S.

description:
I don't like vomiting at work. It makes me look...sick. Not to mention that it fully blows when I have to scrape my own barf off my shoes when I'm not even buzzed.
I went here once before and got some bland Thai Food. Then I went back the other day. My boss was crapping all over the place and I was puking. While an interesting bonding experience I wouldn't recommend it to an enemy. Luckily, it passed in like a day. But I've been wondering was it the oil? Egg? Something in the hair I ate was the ongoing joke at work... Pineapple? Somebody wiped their butt with my food???

AVOID
author: mike l.

description:
I was craving Thai food and saw this place - there was a good sized lunch crowd so thought we should give it a try.  We ordered our food to go - I had the pad thai and thai iced tea and my co-worker ordered the duck curry.  I assumed that it was safe to order the pad thai - how could you go wrong with it, right?  I was wrong - even the thai iced tea did not taste right.  It tasted really bad - not sure if it was the tea or milk, I think they used a powder mix because the flavor was not sweet and it was bitter.  The pad thai noodles were so dry and plain.  I didn't try the duck curry, but it smelled pretty flavorful.  My co-worker said it tasted pretty good.  

I don't think that I will return here for seconds.  There are plenty of Thai restaurants in the city that offer more scrumptious and appetizing dishes that will satisfy my craving.
author: Regina N.

description: Standard Thai fare, which means tasty in my book.  The downstairs is a little musty and the food can sometimes take a while, but it's a good place for lunch if you have an hour.
author: Mike F.

description:
Oh man...  I really don't enjoy their service.  When I am hungry, I just want to get some food, even if not so good one.  I don't really want to have to deal with service attitude.  One day I ordered something to go and the bill came out to $9.97.  I tried using credit card but they wouldn't take it, they said their policy is minimum of $10.  Hello!!!  I'm only 3 cents short!   To top it off, it was late dinner time and raining night, I got off of work late and really just want to dry at home.  
After minutes of arguing, with huge attitude, she finally took my card and said, "next time bring cash".   I thought to myself, next time.. I woudn't come here.

The food isn't all that bad; it's acceptable for thai "fast" food.  Eh..
author: N. C.

description: This place almost made me cry. Granted it was cheap, but I was HUNGRY after licking every bit of sauce left on my plate. Food itself tasted fine, but I think I will give other Thai places a try. 2 hours after lunch, I rushed to Starbucks to grab a pastry, because my stomach kept roaring.
author: Su K.

description: Food is decent, service used to be decent but has since gone to hell, they often forget orders (forgot my appetizer order), bring plates with big time gaps between, difficult to understand waiter can cause the wrong food to be ordered, bs the bill is not in english, affordable.
author: King O.

description:
I should have read Deb I.'s review before ordering here.. 

Got the pumpkin curry also, and I think the captain of the Cosco Busan must be part-timing here while he's waiting for his ship to be allowed to leave the bay, because there was a massive oil spill in my bowl. 

I would have shrugged it off, but it also took an hour for the food to show up, and I was one of the first people sent to the basement seating.

If you're standing in front of this place and want Thai, just walk a few doors over.. its neighbor is a little better.
author: David K.

description:
Good chicken Pad Thai, which is what I always get.  Gets busy during lunch hour.  Has a street-level and downstairs dining area.

Don't like to be seated near the window and look at the people sitting 2 feet in front of me eating outside.  It feels like I'm in a zoo.
author: Casey F.

description: Great for a quick lunch during the work day. Good vegetarian options and the best Thai Iced Tea I've had in awhile. The other reviews claim poor service and food quality- that has not been my experience. I will say, like most SF eateries, it could use a good scrub down.
author: Sarah J.

description:
oooh affordable thai food with good portions in fidi? no waaay!

came here at 12:30 with 3 colleagues and didn't have to wait for a table during lunch rush...nice!

plenty of seating upstairs and downstairs.

free soup if you order a curry or rice plate. spent $12 with tip for mango curry with brown rice and side of salad and soup. totally worth it.

the mango curry was actually pretty bomb with lots of chicken! and the service was good.

i will definitley come back.
author: Kathleen J.

description: Food is salty and unremarkable. The Thai iced tea is below average. The service was good
author: Greg C.

description:
I ordered the spring rolls, thai coffee, and Green Curry with Chicken. Spring rolls were fresh, but greasy. Coffee was good, and the Curry was Spicy! 

Friends ordered Pad-See-You (sp), Soup, and Curry Fried Rice. Noodles were ok, Curry fried rice was great! 

This place was small. Upon enterance you'll see plates stacked up with salads that they add main dishes onto. Tables are small and close together.

Would eat here again, maybe for take-out.

Prices were cheap!
author: J-nine I.

description:
I was so hungry, that I ventured in here with my friend for a quick bite...never thought Thai Food would make me want to barf.

1 - First of all, our table sat eye level with a layer of dust on the kitchen counter - the whole kitchen was exposed to patrons, but that obviously doesn't mean they will go out of their way to make the kitchen spotless. Disgusting.

2 - The first cup of tea I got had FOOD stuck to the rim of my cup. Gross.

3 - The second cup of tea I got had FOOD stuck to the side of the cup. Double Nasty.

4 - The food was cold and tasted like it had been sitting out all day. Do they just reheat things or actually cook them? How many days old was the tofu in my meal? I'm not sure, but it was grainy.... Ewwwww.

5 - The waitress only came to our table when she felt she had to...but there was no one in the restaurant except for a overly-lovely couple who kept kissing. (uhhh...get a private room)

I'll never go back, and I might give a nasty glare every time I walk by. Just awful. Total waste of money. Couldn't eat the food, couldn't drink my tea. The best thing was the white rice...that's just sad.
author: Katy A.

description:
This place gets a lot of flack, but they do Som Tam just the way I like it, incredibly spicy and fresh. I was however, not overly impressed with the spring rolls. They used some weird gelatinous rice paper which did mesh well with the other ingredients.

I have never actually eaten in the restaurant, but find their takeout service to be efficient and courteous. It is hard for me to find good eats downtown in the evening, and being that my Tu/Thurs are 12 hours days, I like having Banana House as an option.
author: C P.

description:
I keep trying to like this place...I try, I reallly do. I try because I love thai food.
I am not a super picky eater either. But tell me how chicken can be dry while it is in soup??? And why is there a layer of oil floating on top of this Tom Yum soup?
I called in a group order, and she kept trying to hang up on me before I was finished ordering. Ok lost in translation there, I dont think it was intentional rudeness. And lastly the price is not great for what you get. Its about the same as some other thai places that I find much more enjoyable.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I had lunch here today for the very first time.  Is this place cramped or what?  My friend and I sat at a tiny table across from one another.  I spent the whole lunch worrying I might accidentally stab him in the eye with a fork.  Not that he doesn't deserve it, but . . .  Just kidding.  The tables were really close to one another, which gave waiters, busboys and patrons an excuse to keep bumping into my chair.

They have a wide selection of standard Thai entrees, ranging in price from $5.95 - $9.95.  For $3 more, you can make your meal a combo (McDonald's flashbacks, anyone?).  $3 more buys you a small salad, 2 small egg rolls, jasmine rice and a Thai iced tea OR a Thai iced coffee.  Most places charge you $3 just for the drink.  Definitely a good deal.

I ordered chicken Pad Thai + combo, and my friend asked for #46.  #46 on the menu was Kaw Nah Gai (sauteed chicken with mushrooms and bamboo shoots in gravy sauce).  For whatever reason, the waitress did not like his order.  She stared at him, then the menu, then reconfirmed - "#46?"  That was all she said to us throughout our entire lunch.  I am still not sure why she was confused by his order.  It's not like he ordered a triple venti non-fat latte or a Fillet-o-Fish extra value meal.

It took a while to get our food.  When it did arrive, the food was mediocre and lacked flavor, but what do you expect for that kind of money?  My Pad Thai was huge, although pieces of chicken were pretty hard to find.  Lots of bean sprouts and crushed peanuts, though.  Still, very filling.  

I might be back, although I am not ready to make it my regular lunch spot just yet.
author: Yan G.

description:
3.5 stars
Pretty good Thai food in a funky atmosphere. We ate here when we were really tired late on a Friday night, it was pretty empty. The service was good, and the curry fried rice and Pad Kee Mao were pretty tasty. Large portions at a decent price, standard Thai fare but nothing out of the ordinary. Good Thai Coffee.
author: Alison M.

description:
Not pretentious, unlikely to draw in throngs of tourists, but quite approachable.

I had the Banana House fried rice, and enjoyed the subtle yellow curry kick (I'm not much for hot spices and often curry is too overpowering for me to enjoy) and every bite seemed refreshingly different than the last.
author: Hans G.

description:
I guess this would be one of those places people would call a "hole-in-the-wall"; very simple decor, KOIT 96.5 (local radio station) blaring as the background music, and bright colors abound. To sum it up, it's got that "fast-food" feel. The view from the main window is only of Kearny Street in all its dirty glory (Kearny Street seems a bit messy for the edge of Financial District/Nob Hill, don't you think?).

Well, aside from the above, I rather enjoyed my quick yet satisfying dining experience at Banana House tonight. The service was great and prompt (food came to me 5 minutes after I placed my order); their menu had the usual curry and noodles, but also had some "Banana House" Specials. I decided to try their Mango Chicken since I love me some protein and some fiber (the fruit). Although I could see the grease swimming in the plate, I still thought the dish was tasty. Rice is ordered on the side, so that costs an extra $1 or $2.

There were also some specials written on their chalkboard behind the counter; apparently they also have Fruit Curry?! That sounded really good to me when I saw it on the board. Alas, I felt I had to get moving after I finished my meal; sadly, the place was empty at the hour (around 6pm), but I imagine (and hope, for the sake of the owners/workers) that the crowd picks up later in the evening.

Banana House is not the best place to take someone for a dinner date, but it seems like a cool place for a casual quick bite for dinner or a lunch date if you work nearby. =)

Oh and p.s. Other pluses of Banana House are the relatively cheap prices (dinner cost under $10 without tip) and there is outdoor seating for those who enjoy sitting outside and watching all the eccentric people walking by.
author: Helene K.

description:
2 things here that I LOVE - 
1) Spaghetti Kee Mao - spicy noodle with spaghetti instead of the wide flat noodle - soooo good; I order this dish at EVERY SINGLE thai restaurant I go to and I think this place does it best
2) Mango chicken - love the sauce and the big chunks of mango

Everything else I've had here is good but not great.... it hits the spot after a long workday - pick it up on my walk home and it's in my belly in less than 10 minutes!  Cant beat it.... wish they delivered to my house; that would be even better!
author: A B.

description:
Went here for lunch today, and it was pretty good.  The friend I met for lunch admitted she had never had thai or indian food, to which I replied, "Wait, WHY do you live here again?"

The food was good, could have been hotter.  There was a LOT of (well cut, well cooked) bamboo shoots in my red curry, and not much bell pepper or basil.

Overall the food earned 4 stars, but I have to dock them for a few reasons-

Service:  Waitresses are abundant, and yet it was nearly impossible to get their attention.  They also dropped the check on our table about 5 minutes after we received our entrees, and, in the absence of cash or a credit card appearing near the check, ignored us while we tried for 10 minutes to order some dessert, and then seemed annoyed that they had to amend our bill.

Fried Banana & ice cream- While it was delicious, it was far from the most appetizing display of this dish I have ever seen.  It just looked kind of strange.

And, just my own personal pet peeve: SPELL YOUR MENU RIGHT.  pumpkin has two p's, and there's no e in broccoli.  It just looks tacky to me when numerous items on the menu are misspelled.  Is this petty?  Yes.  That's why they call it a pet peeve.
author: Adrian L.

description:
I have been here a couple of times for lunch. The pad see ew was pretty good, but the green curry was not good at all. I scooped at least 3 spoonfuls of oil off the curry, yum! 

The service was ok. When I went with a party of 7 they served half the table then about 10 minutes later the other half of the table go their food. I have also been there as a party of 2 and they are quick and attentive. 

This isn't the worst Thai, but it also isn't even close to being the best.
author: Alisa S.

description:
This place is very consistent.  The food is good, the service is good and quick.  My favorites are the Pad Thai noodles, the Garlic Pan with beef, and the Pumpkin Curry with shrimp.

My cousin turned me on to this place and I've since been back with a friend, with my husband, and for some take out.  I've sat upstairs and down, and have to say I prefer upstairs.  The food is really yummy, and I think their portions are perfect for lunch.
author: lea m.

description:
I ordered take-out last Saturday and I was really disappointed.  I usually come here for lunch and the food always seemed pretty good so I thought I would try it for dinner.  I felt it was below average and pretty pricey.  I ordered:

Pad Thai with chicken
Lah Nah Mee Krob with beef
Pumpkin curry with chicken
Praram with tofu
Pad Broccoli

The portions were too small for every dish.  The pad thai was ok, but the noodles were clumpy and stuck together.  There was barely any meat in there.  The lah na mee krob was the best dish of the bunch.  It was really flavorful and I really liked how the noodles soak up the sauce from the meat and veggies.  The pumpkin curry was a little too gingery for my taste.  Praram with tofu was just ok.  The tofu was a bit tough.  The beef with the pad broccoli was tough as well.  
Overall, the bill came out to about $48 with two orders of rice.  I do give them points for packaging the food well.  The peanut sauce for the praram came in its own container as well as the topping for the mee krob.  I won't order take-out again, but I would go back for lunch during the week.
author: Karen K.

description:
I absolutely love this place! I discovered it a couple of years ago during my summer internship in the city, and have kept going back. Their curry is to die for (I recommend the Panang Curry) and their Pad See Ew and Pad Thai rival the best I've had.  
I went to lunch here with a friend yesterday and once again, it did not disappoint. I got my favorite, Pad See Ew chicken, and ate every bite of it.  The portions are generous, and if you get there a little bit before noon, you can get a seat right away and beat the lunch rush.  On sunny days, sit outside and enjoy the delicious food and weather.
author: James C.

description: Tom yum soup was awful!!! My duck salad was ok
author: Christopher L.

description:
Decent Thai food, extensive menu, and reasonable prices. I went there for a late Saturday lunch when it was very pleasant to sit by the big open windows in the front. Good vegetarian selection, and dishes I hadn't seen before, such as the tasty noodle salad with spicy lime dressing that I had.
The fresh rolls (maybe $6.50) were decent but not great. They had what seemed like a flour wrapper, omelette on top, peanuts on the side, and two sauces.
author: Amy E.

description:
Oh, what would dot commers do without all these colorful sit-downs along Kearny Street?  This one is strangely connected with the other Thai restaurant two doors to the left.  Both serve roughly the same food, and Banana House's service is slightly better (or slightly less atrocious) than the other Thai joint.  

Noodle dishes are very tasty, veggie dishes are aromatic and taste just as good, and the drinks are mediocre.  Try the root beer.  It tastes suspiciously like diet coke!   ;)

Refills are not free, and yes I'm a cheapo, but at least they don't roll their eyes and complain about you using a credit card.  One thing that the staffers are missing are SMILES. This is a Thai restaurant, right?
author: Daniel C.

description:
I went there for lunch today (Friday) around 12:45, and I was pleasantly impressed. 

We shared the pad thai and the #21 which is a spicy beef salad. Both were very good, but the salad a little spicier than I expected (I expected bland). 

I really like the interior, it's not kitch as most Thai places are. Our waitress was very nice and attentive without  making us feel rushed, which is how I feel at the other Thai restaurants during lunch hour.

For lunch Thai (which is different from Thai), Banana House is a solid choice.
author: J-Meoww W.

description:
We came across this place because we couldn't figure out where to eat and decided that the 5th restaurant we see would be the place we eat.

The place was small with yellow painted walls, multi-colored wooden chairs, and glass-covered tables.  I ordered the green curry with tofu and made it a combo (salad, rice, egg rolls, and thai iced tea for $3.50 extra).  The food was well presented on the dish and the curry had just enough spicyness.

The service was a tad slow and the egg rolls tasted familiar.. on the way back from the bathroom I see a big box labeled, "Ling Ling egg rolls" hahah frozen eggs rolls that I could have gotten in the grocery store. booo them!
author: Tammie S.

description:
Good for a quick lunch while downtown. 

The traditional fare is tasty, and I have had mixed performances with the mango sticky rice. Sometimes it's good, sometimes inedible.
author: Benjamin T.

description: Cheap and fast.  love this place for surefire curry craving.
author: Hilary C.

description: I have only been here twice, but I enjoyed both meals a lot (mango chicken and pad see you). Really yummy. From the outside and even the inside, the restaurant doesn't seem like anything special, but I'd say it's one of those hidden gems that's worth a try.
author: Julia S.

description:
I've eaten here several times. I don't know why I kept going back, but that temporary insanity has subsided. With lot's of deli choices this seemed like a good option for a warm and filling lunch in the FiDi. However, a trip to this restaurant had to be meticulously planned. The service is very slow so even in the off hours. If I planed on eating in, I didn't bank on making an hour turn around for lunch. For take-out I have to call ahead, even if the restaurant is empty. When I've order a dish with a sauce base, they gave me the sauce and the veggies/ect. in two separate containers so I had to have a bowl or other dish to mix it together at my office. 

All this planning just wasn't worth it as the food is way greasier than it needs to be, the noodles are always over done and stuck to each other, the veggies always seem a bit soggy and the tofu is mushy and either cooked in too much oil or not drained well enough. 

On an upside, it's clean and reasonably priced and the chicken satay is good.
author: Arela R.

description:
The first day of my current work, we had a group lunch meeting here. It was your standard fair of thai dishes. This is one of those thai restaurants that try to cater to the FiDi crowd, keep the presentation a little posh and a food not too spicy. Besides, who wants to go back to work with heartburn. =) Mind you, I like my Thai food with a little kick.

SPACE: Its small and clean and bright. Service was good and prices were about average for FiDi.
FOOD: Nothing particularly stood out, it was good and predictable.
author: Venatius P.

description:
Pad Kee Mao. Order it. It'll burn you non-thai tongue off!

I've come here many times when I used to work a few blocks away from here. Best thai food in the area, hands down. Cheap, quick, and tasty. You might need some thai iced tea to wash it all down, but definitely an experience. If you're in the need for you quick thai food fix, this is it. 

Be aware, there's always a crowd during lunch hour, so best to order take-out, instead of competing for the next open table.
author: Clinton L.

description:
Price - expensive for what it is.
Portions - tiny. Had to go get more food after
Taste - not that good.

Considering the myriad of Thai restaurants in SF, I was disappointed in this restaurant's poor tasting food, small portions, and higher than normal prices. 

The service was VERY slow, even though there were only 3 other people there, and when I asked for more rice (they only give you a small ice cream scoop size) they charged me $1.50 without telling me!

OSHA thai, King of Thai Noodle, Thai Stick, Chaam Thai, are ALL BETTER values, and better taste than this place.
author: V T.

description:
I used to come here all the time for lunch.

Things I love in particular: reasonable prices, delicious Thai iced tea, and very good (and hot!) mango tofu red curry.

It can get a little loud, but I've never experienced a long wait for a table and have always had a good experience.  I've been here many times with coworkers and all the dishes I've shared have been really tasty.  Much higher quality than most of the other overpriced and overrated places in downtown.  

I've also been here for dinner and it is much more mellow and quiet.


And now I'm craving mango curry.
author: Christy T.

description:
Food used to be great. Just ordered 3 different plates and they are all left overs!!! I should have known the delivery was so quick it was suspicious....The soup is old and watery, the shrimps have been heated over and over and are all chewy, the pumpkin curry, is OK but the texture of the pumpkin screams OLD, and the worst is the pad thai the tofu is so old I don't even guess how old it is. 
Bye guys you will never get an order from us again. There are so many thai restaurants in the city... Not worth taking the risk to get left overs.
author: Carpe D.

description:
This place is for people who were born without tastebuds.  That's the only reason I can think a body would want to give this place repeat service.  I am not complaining or angry or pissed at them.  I am just out and out horrified.

It's not that I'm a snob.  Ok, maybe just a little.  But I came to this place expecting perfectly mediocre thai food.  Which I sometimes crave.  And knowing it's going to be perfectly ok, I expect nothing, and sometimes I am slightly surprised.  I thought, hmm... thai place I always pass by on the way to work, cute decor, looks like they have a lunch crowd, looks like they've got repeat customers, maybe I'll finally check it out.

So I did.  Got a mango curry special with an offering of miniscule extras:  pixie sized bowl of soup, iceberg slathered in peanut "dressing" and a single spring roll.  Spring roll, very mediocre, as per expectation.  Maybe a little crispier than I thought, but taste wise, a study in the mundane.  Iceberg in peanut sauce... pushing the border from mediocre to just plain bad, but whatev, I like peanut sauce, even the boring kind.  But the curry?  OH DEAR GOD!   What happened?

Firstly, people, curry is not rocket science.  You grind a bunch of choice, very specific ingredients in a food processor or mortar and pestle if you wanna get hardcore, but either way, the hard part is all done once you got the curry paste.   After that, you got your shallots, palm oil, fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, maybe a kaffir lime leaf or two, and your motherf---kin coconut milk.  Coconut milk is like the mother of all excuse ingredients.   Flunk your final?  Pour some coconut milk on it.  Accidentally piss in the soup?  Pour some coconut milk on it.  Coconut milk is like god's creamy creamy jizz.  Seriously people, this sh-t is not EASY to f--k up.  IT'S HARD.

Granted, I have a very good palate.  But it's very tolerant of other flavors that are not so interesting.   It appreciates the good that often comes masked in the very bad.  But this- salty, bland, oily, utterly devoid of any kind of flavor?  WHAT DID YOU DO?  I want to know so I can recreate this to splash in the face of my enemies.

Of course I was hungry, so I tried to swallow my sorrow and eat around the curry.   You know how you're usually supposed to try to eat things WITH curry?  I picked out my veggies, shook them off, and made do.  I will say this.  Veggies and tofu, perfectly acceptable.  Mango chunks, actually of exceptional quality... well not exceptional... more like the harry and david's of mediocrity.  Yeah.. couldn't eat that curry.  Good thing there wasn't much of it.  And between that and the rice, I was actually able to eat my way to not hungry anymore.  If there had been delicious curry I might have even considered it a meal worth eating.  I also forgot to mention that I got a somewhat bland thai iced tea as part of the "combo."  Unfortunately, the service... kinda poor as well.  Didn't get any water till i asked for some at the end of the meal.  I, personally, don't really care much about service, but maybe somebody will.

Well.   That concludes this review.  I have covered just about everything.   I hope this will convince you not to go.  It's not that eating bad thai food is such a horrible experience.  It's that giving repeat service to an actual bad thai food place is incredibly unnecessary when there are so many perfectly mediocre thai places around.  Heck, maybe someday you may even want to upgrade from mediocre to good!

Oh and for those of you who love this place, I am especially sorry.  The world is so much more interesting when you can taste things.
author: Zoobs L.

description: Went here for dinner. It was deserted. Pra ram was ice cold - I actually asked the waitress to microwave it for me. The sauce was watery. Rice was fine. My date got a Thai iced tea and said it was good. Bill was only $20. I guess you get what you pay for.
author: Erin M.

description: Decent, inexpensive food in a quiet place on the weekend. No rush, no crowds.
author: P K.

description:
Wow!  Banana House is great!

Their Larb Ped (roast duck salad) is really delicious.  Sweet, tangy, spicy, loads of shallots, cilantro and cracked dry rice for crunchy texture.  How many so-called Thai places put toasted, crunchy dried rice in their foods as is done so commonly in Thailand?

The curries are also delicious... good Gang Talay with mussels and squid that's not overcooked.

their street-food appetizers are fairly true to form!  Each one was delicious and their satay peanut sauce is quite good.

on their lunch plates, they could lose the iceberg salad and replace it with a bit of green papaya to make it really shine.

I'll go back again!
author: Greg H.

description:
Why is everyone hyping up the pumpkin curry? I ordered it for lunch today; it was overcooked and lacked a key element: flavor!!

You know a Thai restaurant sucks when they can't make a decent mango sticky rice. How hard can it possibly be?? Banana House's version, just like everything else on their menu, is plated well but is overpriced (pumpkin curry + mango sticky rice = $14!) and bland bland bland.

The Banana Hut is better and it is next door.

A note to plastic mavens like myself: Banana House takes credit cards but you have to spend a minimum of $10, which is not hard to do.
author: Emily D.

description:
I sometimes order the tofu pad thai here to go. It's made fresh when you order and itt's pretty good! The Thai iced tea is pretty good too.

However, I came here to eat with a co-worker a couple of weeks ago. We ordered the pumpkin curry and something else I can't recall. It was just ok. Not very flavorful. Not memorable. I'll be sticking to just getting my tofu pad thai to go.
author: Tammy L.

description: One of the best thai places I've ever been too.  It's cheap, delicious and quickly made.  In and out with take-out within 10 minutes.
author: Mack D.

description:
For being in the financial district this is an okay place for Thai, as its a lot better than its other neighbor Bangkok Best or whatever it is.

I would have given it a 4 stars if it had better customer service.
author: Syonora A.

description:
the place was packed on the first floor for lunch time so we ate in their downstairs area.  it smelled like cleaning solution, otherwise, it wasn't so bad.

i had papaya salad, which was not bad.  it was neat that they gave me raw prawns as requested.  any other place would insist to cook them.

not bad i say.
author: S. T.

description:
Tried this place several times in the month. Food is pretty good. Prices are mostly below $10. Portions are ok.... not huge. No taking extra packed lunch.
Always tried the Thai curries. The best is the Mango chicken curry then the yellow curry.
author: Shiru M.

description:
Cool atmosphere!

Food came slowly.

Yellow curry was good!  Chicken satay good!

Little overpriced for the amount of food.
author: Picky P.

description:
I don't know what they put in the peanut sauce, but I need it like crack.

Eating here at least once a week has become my routine where for the 20 min it takes me to eat it I, am happy to forget the evils of crappy office culture and burned out computer eyes.

The staff is marginally helpful and usually busy as hell.

The atmosphere has a bit to be desired as well.  If your lucky, they will take you to the dungeon where there is not one window and a lingering feeling you might not make it out alive.

But that damn peanut sauce keeps me coming back every week.  The food is so good, reasonable - cheap and worth every penny!  Get the "lunch special" that comes with spring rools, a little side salad and a sweet Thai tea with your meal for $3.00 extra!
author: Brad W.

description: I had the pad thai, and it was fine. No complaints, but nothing to write home about either. Definitely better than "Bangkok Best" next door though.
author: Adam Z.

description:
The first time I went there, I had the dish with the bamboo shoots, and my boyfriend had the spaghetti noodle stir fried with chili oil and pork. My dish stank up the joint when it came out-- it was made with stinky bamboo (not that I minded. Guess my boyfriend did :P). It wasn't bad. The spaghetti wasn't too bad either, according to the boyfriend.
After a while we decided to give the place another try. I ordered a dish with chicken and basil (I forget the name, it's a traditional Thai dish) and my boyfriend got some kind of chicken with different herbs. These dishes come without rice, by the way.
I thought my boyfriend's chicken tasted kind of bland, but maybe that was because my dish was crazy salty. Not only that, but the (overly-) ground chicken bits in it seemed like they cook it in the morning and leave it under a heat lamp for the duration of the day. He tried a small forkfull of mine and started piling his chicken on my plate because he felt bad. 
Guess that's what happens when you go when they're about to close.
author: Karen C.

description:
REDEEMING REVIEW.
This place does not get enough credit.  Fave Thai food I've found in the city so far.  Everything we've had has been excellent.  The prices can't be beat and the flavors are right on.  I'm a Rad Nah/Lad Nah freak, I try it at every Thai restaurant I go to (that has it), and B.H. rocks it!  Convenient location (for us) and friendly service. Casual. Easy. See you next week, House of Banana!
author: Mary Kate B.

description: I got the Spicy Eggplant with Tofu for take-out. It was ready quickly and it was yummy. A bit oily but I think that's on a par with other Thai places that make this same dish. They got it right! Yum.
author: Jamie F.

description: discovery or new taste for pad woon sen....thin silver stir-fry noodles pad woon sen....mission to find various forms of pad woon sen....different locations to pad woon sen.....banana house also pad woon sen...pad woon sen fairly well...mixture of chicken, prawn and vegetables pad woon sen ....telling self pad woon sen healthy....is pad woon sen healthy?...wishing to pad woon sen at home....pad woon sen for lunch...pad woon sen for dinner....banana house pad woon sen portioned "just right"....pad woon sen not as oily or sweet as other pad woon sen experienced....pad woon sen eating bit cramp by interiors....pad woon sen order taking longer than other pad woon sen....pad woon sen service bit slow.....pad woon sen not the specialty of banana house....but, probably more will pad woon sen after reading this pad woon sen subliminal messaging review.....will you pad woon sen with me?...
author: Hen A.

description:
prices for lunch are decent, but a little high for my taste. kind of expected it tho as it's close to the financial district. 

my friend frequents this place a lot for the curry. i decided to nix the curry as i noticed they have udon tom yum. i mean seriously.... i love udon. and i love tom yum. to put them together? genius. pretty good too, i just don't recommend it on a hot day. like today. i was very glad it's casual friday and i got to wear summer clothing. 

i also ordered the thai iced tea. kind of weak. but that could just be me... if i could intravenously inject caffeine into myself i probably would.
author: Jessie H.

description: 3.5 stars. I like this place. They are fast, no frills, good Thai food, good price. I've eaten their number 66 before, Pad Kee Moa, pretty good. Spicy noodles, with tofu and veggies. Take out, under 10 bucks. I also went there recently and sat and ate in the restaurant. Ordered the red curry, which came with a scoop of rice, side salad and fried wontons. Tax and tip=10 bucks! And I was out of there in under an hour! I'll definitely be back again. Decent food, decent price, fast service.
author: Caroline C.

description: Grossly overpriced for what you get at Lunchtime.  Not even a nice room to sit in. Very disappointing.
author: Eric H.

description: soup noodles dishes leave a bit to be desired. the stir fried dishes are better.
author: chet l.

description: Just ate here today, piece of advice: don't make the same mistake I made. Where to start, hmmm, place to small, service too slow, food too dry, assembly line kitchen more focused on take-outs than sit-ins, only one server for the main room, food to cold, food too soggy, food too bland, food too oily, and did I mention the service was slooooowwww. Don't get me wrong, nothing wrong with the people working here, it just felt like they were working in vain with the quality of food that was coming out of the kitchen. Should have gone to King of Thai, damn rubbery legs!
author: Alex C.

description: the food was HORRIBLE and EXPENSIVE. i had some udon soup that tasted ok, my date got the mango chicken, which barely had any chicken, the portion was extremely small for the price, and with drinks the bill came out to $30, my date hated the place so much that she felt bad that i had to pay and offered to pay for her half of the meal........
author: Jaime D.

description:
coworker and i were craving pad thai so badly that we got over our depression over banana hut's closure and ventured to the sister, banana house.  (yes i realize i have developed a recent obsession with pad thai).  

crowded - good sign.  restaurant looked slightly revamped to look more like the hut - another plus.  but the best news is that the pad thai is just as good as it was at hut!  oh the fond memories started to come back as we inhaled the sweet savory peanuty goodness.  i did notice that they also use the thinner rice noodles that osha thai does - is this a new trend?

service is brusque and harried, tables are crowded and the ambiance isn't much, despite the attempt to upgrade.  but the real reason we're here is for the pad thai, which rocks.  a solid 3 stars...
author: Jen P.

description: Big portions and cheap, but the food is mediocre at best. I've had some of the noodle dishes.
author: Joshua S.

description:
i'm just gonna stay DITTO to mike l.'s review... why? because i was the boss that ate the food with him here.

I have eaten their maybe 3 other times before, all somewhat average.  But never any issues.  Until this one time.... story below...

Unless you trying to shed a few pounds thru vomiting or uncontrollable diarrhea, this place is a total NEGATIVE!
author: Deanna T.

description: Good selection and good salads and the prices are decent.  I really liked the spicy eggplant tofu with a side of white rice.  The atmosphere won't win any awards but if are looking for a quick bite of some flavorful Thai then this is a good choice.
author: Rob C.

description: I have to say...I am impressed everytime I order. I work on the weekends in the financial district and they are the only restaurant open, practically....thank god they rock! I would starve if their food was not all that.... believe me, even if there were others open, I would still go to Banana House. Great service, food presentation and price. Just perfect!
author: Isabel L.

description:
this place wasnt terrible but it definitly wasnt good. i was with a group of 4 other people, we tried various dishes including the coconut milk soup, a few chicken dishes and fish. the fish was cold and rubbery, the soup was blah and the chicken well, it was okay once smothered in sauce.

for the price, its what youd expect. i however wasnt expecting to be up all night with tummy troubles. based on that i definitely dont think ill be back here ever again. or any other thai place for that matter. yuckie.
author: Britney K.

description: Had lunch here and the duck curry is delish! Great for a short lunch, but it can get pretty hot inside during the spring and summer seasons.  Some of the food can get pretty spicy, so be sure to let them know ahead of time what you can handle.
author: Jin B.

description: I've gone here once and a while for a few years now, and find the quality to be pretty inconsistent.  I've tried the fried rice, the tom ka gai, and the curries, and they are sometimes kind of good, and sometimes just not good.  I finally settled on the yellow chicken curry as my main item, a small dish with rice for almost $9.  Yesterday it was so hot I could barely eat it.  There were way too many chili or red pepper flakes in it, and I had to take a gulp of water after every bite.  I think it's time to find a new Thai place.
author: hag a.

description: The only reason I give BH a 4 instead of a 5 is because the decor is simply shitty and ugly.  I work about a 1/2 of a block away from this joint and the Tom Yum Gai is SUPERB! I'm very picky about my Tom Yum and it's outstanding. It's always hot in temperature and HOTTER in spice (especially if you ask for it HOT).  The service is quick, especially during lunch (never been for dinner) and we all know that's important during a lunch hour.  It's decently priced as well. I can get out of there with a bowl of Tom Yum, a diet coke, and brown rice $10.  Great place to chow down with friends during your lunch hour.
author: Jenny W.

description: This may also be known as 'Banana Leaf' as I dont think the sign says banana house anymore.  The food is excellent, its vegan vegetarian friendly (ask for no fish sauce) and the service is usually very quick.  However the portions are not large.  Enough to fill you up but for $7+ I usually expect more.
author: Joshua S.

description: Great Thai restaurant.  Their Pad Thai is one of the best for downtown SF.  This place gets very packed during the lunch rush though, so either get there early, or be prepared to wait.
author: Minh V.

description: On 9/12 I ordered food for 3 people which consisted of 6 dishes with rice (approx $50 worth of food). Note, I have ordered from this restaurant 4 other times with no problems - in fact, the food is generally pretty good. However, on that night, the driver would not come up to my door - she insisted that I must go DOWN to the front of my building to pick up my food (which is lazy and stupid IMHO). So I did - when I got there, she then told me it took me TOO LONG to go down there and normally she would just be allowed to leave. How rude! No, she did not receive a tip. On top of this, 1/2 of our order was completely wrong. And the food that was right? It was disgusting. I will never order from here again.
author: Michael D.

description: This is one of the few places that I would ding on the "stars" for the outright disappointing environment.  All around good food.  I would recommend the curry sampler (green, red and yellow), which will fill you up and never let you down.  Red, Green, then Yellow is my ranking on each of them with medium to hot flavor.  Just don't go there for lunch during the weekday lunch hour, because most likely (at least in my experience) you will get seated downstairs... and downstairs smells disgusting.  Like siting in a large concrete cell block with a bunch of hungry people, and you walk out satisfied but odorous.  The best is to hit this place on an off hour or a weekend and on a warm day and sit outside.
author: Matt C.

description: If you're looking for typical a avant-garde, chic restaurant in downtown San Francisco, this isn't it. The upstairs is a bit nice, because of the light coming in from the windows, but downstairs is more of a cellar-turned-extra seating space. However, the food is quite satisfying, and the prices aren't exorbitant for San Francisco. I would avoid the joint at lunch, however, as hoards of young investment bankers and other young professionals tend to pour into this place between 12 and 1.
author: Rachel K.

description: This place is also near my hubby's office.  We've eaten here a few times, once in the dungeon and a few times on the main floor where we squeezed together at a table for one.  Based on previous experiences, I would probably have given this place 3 stars, the food is okay, but when we ate there last week and noticed cockroaches crawling around the wall above the kitchen, we were thoroughly grossed out and vowed never to go back.
author: Angela O.

description:
ordered takeout from the Banana Hut, b/c i love the Banana Hut... went to Banana Hut once and it was great, really loved it... so we order some dinner from the Banana Hut... go to pick up from the Banana Hut... but it wasn't the Banana Hut at all... but rather the goddamn motherfucking Banana House instead... right next door... Banana Hut next door to the Banana House right next door to the fucking Banana Pavillion or something. 

fuck

.
author: michael w.

description: I found a six inch long hair in my eggplant with chicken today.  'Nuff said.  At least they gave me my money back.
author: Scott L.

description: So it would have gotten more stars, as the food is outstanding, but they were blarring KOIT.  Give me a couple valium before I listen to that "easy listening" crap.  But the food was great, curry-rific!!
author: Mickey D.

description: I came here for lunch, and surprisinly seating wasn't a problem. The downstairs was more spacious than the upstairs level. I ordered the pad kee mao, and it was too spicy for my liking. I wish they scraped some seeds out from the jalapenos before cooking with the dish. And the pad thai was...blah. Nothing to rave about.
author: Wendy L.

description: I really wanted Thai for lunch one work day and this was the closest place. The food was underwhelming and the waitstaff was so slow! I had to practically jump out of my seat to flag one over to get the bill. It's one thing if the place was busy but I deliberately took a late lunch to miss the lunch rush. Also, one waitress was counting her tips right in front of me. Klassy.
author: Nathalie L.

description: For a minute, I was worried that I was the only one who didn't like Banana House... but then, I realized that I don't care.  My experience with the service was not very favorable, and we got stuck in the basement during the lunch rush.  If you're ever down there, maybe you can tell me what that smell is?  Someone must has stuck a sign on my back as I was leaving the office saying "ignore me, screw up my order, and whatever you do, don't refill my water."  Oops.
author: Andrew H.

description: There're few to no good Thai places in this area, so when I got a craving today, I thought I'd give this place a second chance. Boy, was that a mistake. I ordered Pad see ew. The service was curt and unfriendly. The portion was small and unsatisfying, and the worst part: the food was burnt! Unless they're experimenting with cajun-Thai fusion, there is no excuse for the low quality of my food. This is my last trip to Banana House.
author: Nicholas F.

description: I was feeling pretty generous with my reviews tonight, but this place I just can't find a way to go beyond 2 stars and only because they were nice. This place is dirty, unless you are into rice and food leftovers on the wall, and the food is not good, I'm not even sure it is edible. Sorry guys, you are so nice, but you gotta step it up. The hood is changing....
author: Buckeye W.

description:
This a mediocre, lunch spot in the FiDi. I like that it is staight forward eating. You walk in and if there is no line you are quickly seated. You are handed a menu, with very little enthusiam, and promptly seated. I am a very plain person when it comes to Thai, I have not yet learned to branch out, so I always get the Pad Thai or the Pad See ( I think that is the Thai version of Chow Fun) It is not anything to really rave about but it is good!! The noodles are always cooked to perfection and usually don't have to wait long to eat. I have been with co-workers and we have all aggreed the following dishes are good
Pad Thai
Pad See ( Once again I think this correct)
Fried Rice
Fried Rice w/ Fried Chicken
The combo deal with the salad, and rice
Kung Pao Chicken
****** The Thai Ice Tea is GREAT********
All in all this is a nice place to grab lunch, and enjoy  a good afternoon in the city! However if you can, avoid sitting downstairs where there are scented candles that could kill ANY MEAL!!!
author: Ashlei T.

description: We like this place for thai lunch. Close to our office, good prices and tasty. I usually like to order a rice noodle dish like pad see ew or pad kee mao or a soup. Never had a bad dish here.
author: Alexandra D.

description: I give them 2.5 stars for flavor, 1 star for price and value. I got a to-go lunch. $9 for maybe 5 bites of noodles. It was the smaller of the to-go containers and it was not even half full. The only thing that was plentiful was broccolli. The pad kee mao was standard, tasted fine, not bad not great. Too bad it wouldn't have been enough to feed a small cat. Ridiculous. $9 and I am still starving. Will never go again.
author: Raptor J.

description: This place is just so-so. The good thing is that it is open at night and is one of the few restaurants near Belden that obviously is not on Belden - i.e., somewhere good but cheap. So, I usually go here after happy hour. I went last night and ordered the prik khing - string beans, basil and your choice of meat. It was $7.95 but came in this teeny tiny little container. I guess I am used to "normal" places where they have normal sized containers. They charged $1.50 for rice, but came out to $10.25. I guess you can't expect too much eating downtown.  As for the food - it is average. Not spectacular but not horrible.
author: Natalie S.

description: Really good Thai food in the financial district. This place is one of the most authentic thai joints I've encountered and makes the best pad thai I've tasted in the city. The cute wait staff don't hurt either.
author: Stellah D.

description: The green curry was good, but I would say the portion size was a bit disappointing for $9 dish.
author: Kitty N.

description: Food is ok but quality is consistent.  I really like their Pad Woon Sen (silver noodles).  They deliver too, which is a total plus while working late nights and a better alternative to Waiters on Wheels.
author: Winnie L.

description: Pretty damn good! My friend Angela K. actually introduced me to this little gem :o) Great spicy garlicy  basily chicken! Enjoy it while you can but I warn you to not wash it down with soda. Soday only makes you burp and will all the spiciness may cause discomfort to those who surround you.  Make sure you come to this place with a good friend or an enemy if you order any of their special spicy goodnesses (is that even a word?)
author: Aim E.

description: Perfect for lunch when I am craving Thai food.  The Pad Kee Mao is my favorite and is always spicy, just as the name says.  It gets crowded during the lunch rush, so be sure to arrive before noon if you want a table and you should be fine. Service is quick and efficient, they definitely get you in and out of there fast.
author: Carolyn K.

description: found this place by just walk pass with my hubby check out the menu seems like a lot of selection for a small little place,nobody inside (it;s Saturday evening)the owner came out and tell us that they're open,so we just sit down not too hungry get 2 entrees to share with steam rice add $3.50 extra to get a Thai peanut sauce salad ,Thai ice tea and jasmine rice.We order traffic jam curry and Phad Nor Mai(stir-fried bamboo shoots with basil and chicken)they use all white meat chicken .Good portion for the price ,fast  service,the waitress there very attentive .Didn't expect anything just want to check out left the place not disappointed ,great  location(close to my work) definitely will go back there again.
author: J N.

description: I eat here often.  the food is consistently good, not great, but doesn't disappoint.
author: Keith B.

description: Not bad Thai, especially with the limited selection of restaurants immediately in the financial district.  Always busy, but quick during lunch.  Pretty cheap for sit-down Thai food--but expect no frills dining.
author: Lucas M.

description: Yummy, cheap eats and good food.. MUST get the Papaya Salad...
author: Aimee C.

description: Decent Thai food with medicore service.   They can be awfully slow at times. But the food is decent. I love their fried fish! Can't remember what it is call. But I order it everytime I go there.  It take a bit longer than the regular dishes but it is REALLY good.   All in all, decent Thai food on the fly for the Financial Districts workers.
author: Chris C.

description: This place is an office favorite, although after they lost some of their staff to the secession of "Banana Hut" next door the service has definitely suffered. I'm a Kra Prow person, but the eggplant lovers always seem very happy and the "Traffic Jam" curry combo is a favorite. It ain't fancy, it ain't the finest Thai food, but it's close and satisfying and the basement almost always has room for a group.
author: mahi m.

description: Very tasty, non-greasy food. Great place for lunch.
author: Joy C.

description: I've been eating here for 6 years. During lunch this place is packed, they are fast and the food is good. I love spicy food but some times it is over the top hot. I just ask to tone it down a bit.
author: Vanessa N.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant downtown.  It's great for lunch.
author: Heinz G.

description:
Banana House's menu impressed me, but its execution disappointed me.  The well-organized menu contains quite a variety of dishes and combinations beyond the standard Thai options available in the Bay Area, plus they have specials, and the descriptions leave your mouth watering.

The taste of the food, however, left something to be desired.  I ordered cashew chicken, which is my barometer for judging a Thai restaurant, since this was a favorite dish to eat while in Thailand and Thai places around Asia.  

In Banana House's version of cashew chicken served to me, some of the onions were undercooked, while the others were nearly flavorless.  Several hours later I still tasted the onion in my mouth.  Also, BH used white onion instead of the red onion that normally comes with cashew chicken.  

The presence of chilis in the dish added no perceptible heat, which was disappointing.  Pineapple was also added to the dish, but it didn't add much taste because it was either overcooked or came from a can.

As for the sides that came with my lunch special, the salad dressing was far too sweet.  The fried wonton wrappers were my favorite part of the meal: thin & crispy, almost to the point of melting in your mouth; however, these were provided more as a garnish, not in a quantity sufficient to thoroughly enjoy.

On the plus side, Banana House does have fairly ample seating (we found a seat for two at 1230pm), and isn't too loud or chaotic, so you can meet here, sit, and have a conversation while you eat.  Good for friends and same-level colleagues.  Not too romantic, but space is cozy, so you can easily end up in close proximity to your companion, if that's what you're after. 

Overall, very average California Thai.  2.4 stars.
author: movinon ..

description: This is my favorite lunch place in the financial district.  It's a good value, the food is excellent, and there are two floors of seating.  It may even be one of my favorite Thai places ever.  Oh and if you tell them you want it spicy, they listen.  =)
author: angela k.

description: my server was a bit rude, the food was just okay. On a cold and windy day here in SF, don't go here for lunch. They leave the door open and if by chance you're seated at the table by the closed door, expect a draft. Don't think I'll go back here to dine but maybe I'll do take-out if I get desperate.
author: Lola D.

description:
I loved this place, the food is so great, especially the Mango Curry, it is very great! Very fresh, with a very reasonable price. I saw they tried to use very fresh veges and meat, fruit, so it shows me they are very honest to offer the food. 
One thing I really liked here is the clean kitchen. They have 98 scores on the SF health department post card. 
Love it!
author: Jacy G.

description: it's not the greatest ever, but for a quickie lunch spot in the finincial district it's perfect.  they're quick, friendly and they make a good pad thai.  I've brought friends and never gotten a complaint.
author: Chad K.

description: Again... I like the people at my work... randomly strolled up Kearny to find Banana House (mmm Thai)... it was cramped and a little loud... but over all it was quick service, pretty well priced... and so close to work I can not complain (except that my pumpkin curry was made with butternut squash... they are not the same people).
author: Jordan Y.

description: Ehh.. I decided to try Banana House because they looked pretty slow & I only had 30 minutes to eat dinner. I ordered #40 which the menu says is $7.95. She asked me what type of meat. I chose tofu. She asked if white rice was okay. I said yes. My total was $10.55. Uhhh... okay.. apparently the white rice that I okay'd was $1.75. Basically I paid almost $11 for a half cup of really spicy green beans, a few cubes of tofu, & a tiny box of rice. Totally overpriced. I've had much better for much less.
author: sara j.

description: Thought the food was good. Used to go about once a week. Service was friendly if scattered. Then...there was a dead cockroach in my curry. Literally. Server promised she wouldn't charge me for it. Which was very nice of her. Can't get over it. Can't go back. Yuck.
author: Michelle B.

description:
I live nearby, I've eaten here for lunch and dinner. 2-3 times a month. The food is good & dependable, service is quite good, don't know why so many low marks. 

They'll make you mild curry if you want (without looking at you cross eyed).
Tasty Thai Ice Tea!
author: nathan r.

description: I've been here for takeout and have generally been happy.  It's a little more expensive than my preferred Thai place, but it is a lot closer to work (less than a block).  They got me my curry fairly quickly, so points for that.  The food was pretty good, but not as flavorful as other places (i.e. about average).  Basically, nothing too eventful in terms of a Thai restaurant (but I would eat there again).
author: Ryan M.

description: I love this place.  I eat here twice a week. The service is fast, friendly, and the food is always good.  The yellow curry is my favorite.
author: Robin C.

description: I really wanted to like this place too. I ordered the Prik Sod and the vegetables were sooooo hot that I just couldnt eat it.  The chicken was good and so was the rice and salad but had a hard time eatting it because of the spicy/hot aftertaste that lingered on. I tried to order my lunch ahead of time at 11:30 and got a busy answer several times so had to go there and wait for what felt like eternity which isnt normally a big deal if I really enjoyed the food. My nose is still running from the hot-spiciness. I probably wont go back after learning someones elses green beans were super hot. Sorry!
author: Darlene R.

description: Having enjoyed the Banana House twice now, I feel confident Yelp-ing it up. It's never easy to know where you'll end up during that precious one hour lunch break. Could be a burrito, could be a burger, could be thai food. Today I chose thai and walked straight to Banana House. Don't need to worry about waiting, the restaurant is deceptively large with a downstairs dining area. Service is prompt and the food arrives quickly, they understand that we are confined to the constraints of time and supervisors. Entrees are all about $7 and the selection is enough to overwhelm. All dishes are available as vegetarian or carnivore. Many of the dishes include fish sauce, vege/vegans should ask for no fish sauce. Overall, it's standard thai fare with good flavors.
author: Alex D.

description: If you are in the mood for Thai go directly to Banana House.  We had dinner on a Sat. night so it was not too busy as it is during the week.  The food is excellent.  The papaya salad is a bit spicy but not over the top-very good.  The chicken satay was tender and the sauces get a big YUM!.  The spring rolls were a surprise with the egg on top, but delicious all the same.  Our entrees were very generous portions, but not excessive.  The pumpkin curry with chicken was probably my favorite, nice combo of sweet and spicy.  The mango chicken was very good, a nice dish for those new to Thai food.  The yellow curry with chicken needed a little more potato for my plate, but flavors right on.  We were too full to eat dessert. But I bet that would have been delicious as well.  The server was pleasant, attentive and answered our questions with a smile.  A very good value for the quality of the food - particularly in SF.  Go to Banana House!!!
author: Terry M.

description: i have only ordered to go plates and items from here. good thai food in the FiDi. service is good and the dishes are tasty but they don't understand special instructions and handling those requests accordingly like for instance, asking to not spice it up so much but it ends up being more spicy than before.
author: Mika D.

description:
im not particularly a thai person, but i ate here twice in one day and plan to be back often. all the guys i ate with said it was really authentic. and one of them was chinese. the menu was quite extensive. the lunches all hover around $7. you order by number which is fun. i mean, who doesnt like ordering the the #47 and then hearing the waiter say '#47 is my favorite?' 

well you know what buddy? #47 is now my favorite too. good times.
author: the sternkid ..

description: i had the thai red curry with shrimp and pumpkin.  the curry was really oily and super spicy... like overly spicy that i can't taste my food.  it also cost like 12$ just for the curry with a small thing of rice.  meh.  i can get better thai food almost anywhere.
author: H. L.

description: after a fantastically boring morning of an extremely long and pointless seminar, my coworker and i decided to ditch the bland turkey sandwiches they were providing for lunch and snuck off to the banana house for some thai food. first impression of the place, it looked like a high school cafeteria lunch line and smelled like one too. i was a bit weary and edging towards the door, but my coworker was steadfast and dragged me to the nearest table to enjoy their newly opened full service seating. i'm so glad he's stronger than me. i had the garlic beef and rice dish. it was perfect! just the right amount of spices and flavor. i'm in love with their peanut butter salad dressing. i had to stop myself from licking the plate. all in all a really good experience for really not that much money. i hope i get to ditch seminar luncheons again.
author: Aly L.

description: the corn cake appetizer was delicious, setting my expectations higher than the the curry main course could reach. it feels unfair to rate this place without having tried the fruit curry, so perhaps i will return to see if the dish is as good as it sounds, and also if banana house deserves an extra star.
author: shannon e t.

description: magic for yo mouf!!! this place is awesome. happy salmon (i'm not sure if it's on the menu, but it's the salmon curry). and the fbi...to die for. yum yum yum. eat there, or be square. or just hungry.
author: MrBoomBastic ..

description: disappointing. soggy garlic prawns, the worst mango-sticky rice i've ever tasted, and non-impressive pad see-ew and basil chicken. the order of prawns was TINY too. not worth it!
author: I. K.

description:
Yay! I found it. Thai food with the subtlety of what Thai food should taste like (my sister-in-law is Thai and I have had some of the best Thai food ever). First, ordered at 8:00, food arrived for delivery at 8:30 (to SOMA/Financial District). Next, the variety was great and there were some dishes I'd never had. Lastly, some of it was just so yummy. If you like spicy (which I don't), they have spicy. If you like mild, mostly they have mild (not always). The Coconut chicken lime soup (I don't have menu in front of me and I'm bad at Thai but think it is Tom Ka Ghai), awesome, jasmine rice, so good, green chicken curry, so good, eggplant, awesome. I asked for mild on everything, however, some of the other dishes were a bit spicy for my taste. But, they were listed as spicy, and I asked for them mild, so I accept that I am a spice sissy. But, I will definitely be going back/calling again, yummy, yummy food.
I read these other reviews, not sure if I just have a different idea of what good Thai food is. I have been looking and looking for a good Thai place, nothing has compared to the good Thai food I've had before I got here, til this.
author: Hayley S.

description: i like the two little thai places along kearny. they are quick, cheap, and very tasty. it's pretty much my low cost thai spot for lunch. takeout is good too. the place is a bit small, but the servers are very nice.
author: Alex L.

description: a good place downtown for a quick lunch. the spicy pork and string beans is my favorite, and i love that they serve lunch meals with a small salad. their pad thai is ok, if you are craving it, but not outstanding. overall, perfectly fine food, but nothing to write home about.
author: oona m.

description: My friend and I ordered the food and it never came. We waited for 45 min (how dumb we were!) and saw (white) people who came much later than we did got their food, and then their bills. We asked both waitresses but they did not even check the order. 45 min later, one waitress came and told us that we can leave if we want. (with the attitude like we're dirt) No explaination of what happened to our order!! This so-called restaurant deserves 5 negative stars for the staffs.
author: Bias W.

description: I order from this place at least once a week.  I always get Satay Tofu, Pad Kra Prao and/or Yellow Curry.  Fast delivery because they are only two blocks away from my office.  No complaints so far...
author: Jay L.

description: Okay food. Nothing spectacular. Sad to say, but I'd much rather eat at King of Thai anytime over this. This place has.. you can say the "right" portions (thats for the ladies).. but small for the gents. hahaha
author: Dianne I.

description: This place has gone down hill dramatically - both eating in and their delivery.  The brown rice issue is always a disaster.  I go in, I sit down, order, start drinking my coke, time passes after they take my order, and they finally come tell me they have no brown rice.  Why didn't they know when I walked in the door and asked if they had it before I even sat down?  I called for delivery the other night, asked if they had brown rice, they had to check, they said  they had enough for one order.  I asked if this meant it was the bottom of the pot and old (the previous time I ordered it was obviously the bottom of the pot - you know how it cakes together?).  After seeming to not understand, they finally understood and said yes, it was old.  I thanked them for their honesty and hung up.  If I wouldn't have asked, they once again would've sent bottom-of the pot yucky rice.  Overall the portions have gotten unacceptably small and the food is tasteless chunks of stuff swimming in oil.  Too bad.
author: G C.
